courses.title: Learning Redis
courses.synopsis: Redis—an in-memory data structure store—differs from relational databases like MySQL, and NoSQL databases like MongoDB. In this course, learn what Redis is and how it works as you discover how to build a client implementation using an ioredis client and a Node.js server. Emmanuel Henri explains how to install and set up Redis, and covers basic Redis tools and concepts, including persistence and replication. Plus, he reviews the different data types available, and demonstrates what you can do with strings, hashes, and lists. To wrap up, he goes over security options and best practices for securing a Redis instance.
objectives: Reviewing the basics of data types
courses.comments:
Along with the learning objectives listed above, we also covered sets and sorted sets, and had a brief intro to Redis Sentinel and Redis Cluster.
We used the command line Redis client, and coded in Node.js, importing the ioredis Redis client package.
I wrote Windows batch files to start the main and replication servers, and the client, passing authorization.
And I found a GUI client for Windows, RediNav.
I also installed and configured Redis on an Ubuntu instance of WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux). And I installed it on one of my Hyper-V VMs of Ubuntu (Kubuntu), set up persistence, replication and security, and installed a GUI (Another Redis Desktop Manager) for it there. I also wrote shell scripts to start the replication server, and the client, passing authorization.
And I downloaded Docker images/containers of Redis and of the Redis-Commander GUI client.
I also created a Redis Cloud account.

UPDATE (the next day): As the Windows version of Redis is just a port, and the instructor used a Mac, I went back and installed and configured it on my Mac. I also went and set the PATHs there, and in WSL and Kubuntu, which I hadn't done, so that I could run my shell scripts from anywhere in the terminal on those platforms.
I changed the bindings in the Redis config files on my Mac and Ubuntu VM, so that I was allowed to connect to those instances from the RediNav GUI in Windows. I then created connections to those in RediNav.
WSL already acted as 127.0.0.1, so I changed the config files there to use different ports (for the main and replication servers), so I could have and access distinct databases in Windows and WSL.
I also created connections to the WSL servers in RediNav.
And I wrote a Windows batch file to connect to the different port of the WSL main server with the Redis command line client from Windows at the same time.

courses.title: Python 3.10 First Look
courses.synopsis: If you’re a regular user of Python, you’ve probably noticed that Python is frequently updated with new features, improvements, and applications. It can be hard to keep up with all the changes, but it’s important to stay current with the Python language. In this short course, Claire Burn walks you through the newest Python enhancement proposals in Python 3.10, as well as the module improvements and the deprecations introduced in this new version. She also demonstrates how to port to Python 3.10 from an older version, no matter what operating system you're using. If you’re looking for a quick look at Python 3.10 and don’t want to spend time wading through all the documentation, join Claire in this course.

courses.title: Python Tools: Jupyter vs. PyCharm
courses.synopsis: As Python has risen in popularity, there are many tools and repositories that have also become increasingly important. Of the many that are available, Jupyter and PyCharm have emerged as leading tools. In this course, software engineer and instructor Sam Pettus provides you with the baseline knowledge you need to work effectively with both Jupyter and PyCharm, as well as determine which option works best for you. Sam begins by detailing the difference between integrated development environments (IDEs) and open-source web applications, as well as how each of these tools function. Sam then walks through the key differences between each tool when working on a data science project, including topics such as debugging and integrating data. He then goes over the user profiles that most commonly leverage each program, giving you the ability to make a decision between the two depending on the project or task at hand. After watching this course, you'll be familiar with the pros, cons, and use cases for each programming tool.  This course was created by Madecraft. We are pleased to host this training in our library.
courses.comments:
I've used Jupyter Notebook and Visual Studio Code (and other tools) for programming Python, but not PyCharm. I'd seen mention of PyCharm, and this course has inspired me to queue up a PyCharm course here.
The instructor thew in some things about debugging in Jupyter that I hadn't learned yet.
He also mentioned nbextensions for Jupyter Notebooks.
PyCharm has a nice built-in (in the Professional Edition) code profiler feature.

courses.title: Postman Essential Training
courses.synopsis: Automated API testing is one of the most efficient ways to ensure that an API is behaving as expected—faster and far superior to automated UI testing. For testers and developers responsible for API testing, Postman is a popular and free solution. It offers a rich interface for writing test cases and features for automation, such as the ability to reuse tests and integrate collections into a CI build system like Jenkins. This course introduces the process of writing, running, and automating API tests with Postman. Instructor Kristin Jackvony shows how to create a complete test collection; create easy and advanced assertions, including nested JSON assertions; run collections with the built-in collection runner and the command-line runner, Newman; and configure automatic runs in Jenkins projects.
objectives: Creating GET, POST, PUT, and DELETE requests
Running collections with the collection runner and Newman
Automating test collections as Jenkins projects
courses.comments:
An excellent course! And a good follow-up course that expands on the Introducing Postman course I completed here.
Here, we used a different way to organize our Requests - in the Introducing Postman course, we created valid and invalid Examples under a Request. Here, we used a separate Folder for Negative Requests, which helped for our automated testing runs.
We learned about saving Response data as a Variable, using JavaScript and the Postman API.
We also added Tests, via assertions, checking response Status, and values in the returned Body.
We used the Collection Runner, to run through all (or just selected) tests from within Postman.
Then we exported our Collection and our Environment to run with Newman, from the command line.
We also installed and configured Jenkins, for scheduling our Newman tests.
I had problems starting the service when running the Jenkins MSI, so after some online research on the problem, I ran the Java .war file after copying out the Jenkins folder mid-installation, then cancelled the installation.
Then I opened the generated local Web site, and installed the Windows service from there, as well as adding the NodeJS plugin.
I also went ahead and generated and published the Contact List API Documentation, as I learned to do in the prior course.

courses.title: Introducing Postman
courses.synopsis: Postman is essentially like a graphical cURL. But if you’re only using it as such, then you’re missing out on some of the API development environment’s most interesting and useful features. In this course, instructor Dave Fancher highlights some of this key functionality as he shares how to best leverage Postman to enhance your API development experience. Dave shows how to work with a sample API to compose and authenticate requests, how to view and publish documentation, how to manage environments and variables, and more.
courses.comments:
I'd used Postman before, but mainly just running/testing ad-hoc Requests. This course covers the Postman UI, with a focus on using the features to organize and document APIs.
We covered the following:

* Collections and Folders — to organize and save Requests

* Setting up Authorization — at a Collection level, so that it applies to every Request in that Collection

* History — to save and name Requests already used

* Saving examples — e.g., of valid and invalid Requests, and their Responses

* Adding Documentation

* Publishing Documentation — so that it displays as a Web page

   I made a slight change to the styling (for the code background color):
   LinkedIn - Introducing Postman Course API Documentation

* Variables — can be used in Requests, as well as elsewhere throughout Postman

NOTE: The Postman UI has changed since this course was published, so you get to some things a bit differently now than as shown.

courses.title: Agile Testing
courses.synopsis: Learn how to create higher-quality software at a faster clip by implementing agile testing in your organization. Throughout this course, instructor Ash Coleman helps you boost your understanding of the role and methods of software testers, as well as how testing can enhance your agile workflow. To kick things off, Ash goes over the role of the tester in agile teams, detailing how testers govern, monitor, and encourage quality practices. Next, she steps through the agile testing approach and pinpoints where testers can add value. She also helps to acquaint you with key testing processes and responsibilities, including bug tracking; explores both manual testing and test automation; and discusses how continuous integration can be incorporated into the mix.
objectives: The role of the agile tester
courses.comments: A good overview of the Agile process(es), focusing on a Tester role.

courses.title: How Blockchains Will Change Business
courses.synopsis: Blockchains are poised to disrupt entrenched industries and shatter conventional business models. Train your brain to see the opportunities and challenges of this next wave of digital change, before the way we do business is again reshaped by new technology. This jargon-free course can help you get up to speed. Join Alison McCauley, the best-selling author of Unblocked: How Blockchains Will Change Your Business (and What to Do about It), as she goes over what blockchains offer companies, as well as how this technology will impact everything from finance to HR.  Alison begins by explaining what blockchains accomplish, how they make it safer for everyone to work together, and where they do—and do not—deliver value. Then, she details the new tools that blockchains offer business, including how they can help you discern what's real from what's false in your digital world. Plus, learn how blockchains can impact different departments within your business, from finance to HR.
courses.comments: This course was more recent than the other blockchain-related courses I have taken here, and provided some examples of how businesses are already using blockchains, and a lot of good ideas and examples of how blockchains could be used in the future.

courses.title: Tips for Better Business Writing
courses.synopsis: Want to advance your communication skills? Improve your writing. Clear and concise writing is the key to helping your audience understand your message—whether it’s delivered in an email, report, memo, or white paper. This course, designed by Adcom Designs and Write It Well managing director, Natasha Terk, provides relevant, actionable tips to improve the quality and impact of your writing. Learn how to plan a message, format it for easy reading, and use the right words to communicate clearly. Plus, learn how to reduce or eliminate errors to maintain your professional image and credibility.
objectives: Describe the two fundamental purposes of business writing.
Define a key message, and explain how and where to use it.
Explain how to generate a list of points for discussion and logically organize that list.
Quantify appropriate sentence lengths for ease of understanding.
Describe the importance of proofreading and list strategies for identifying errors.
courses.comments:
I saw that some former coworkers had taken this course, and although I think that I'm already pretty good at this, I figure that I can always improve.
As in another writing course that I'm taking here, this one emphasizes the fact that readers of such communication tend to scan more than engage in close reading, and offers ways to facilitate that for them.
It also offers advice on how to be more concise, and since I can sometimes suffer from what Mark Twain was referring to in a letter to a friend, I appreciated his line:
"I didn't have time to write a short letter, so I wrote a long one instead."

courses.title: Blockchain: Learning Solidity
courses.synopsis: Blockchain is a buzzword, but it's also a very powerful technology that allows everyday users to exchange sensitive data without a middleman. Programmers can leverage the blockchain in their applications using Solidity, a programming language for the Ethereum platform. This course teaches you how to build a simple contract-based application with Solidity. Emmanuel Henri starts with the basics of blockchain and smart contracts: self-executing transactions written directly in code. You can then learn all about the Solidity ecosystem, including syntax and advanced concepts such as source mappings, then apply them to build your very first contract.
objectives: Solidity programming basics: types, variables, functions, and conditionals
Creating a smart contract in Solidity
courses.comments:
Solidity is a programming language for the Ethereum platform.
We used the Remix online IDE/compiler, where we coded and tested a Smart Contract (having to do with payouts from an inheritance).

courses.title: Blockchain: Beyond the Basics
courses.synopsis: Blockchain is an exciting new technology that is redefining how we store, update, and move data. Learn about the blockchain and the implications of decentralized, encrypted data storage for business and society, in this course with Dr. Jonathan Reichental. He begins by explaining exactly how the blockchain works, including the concepts of cryptography, mining, distribution, and smart contracts. Next, he describes how the blockchain enables the most popular cryptocurrency, bitcoin. Learn how new bitcoin is generated, how it is transacted, and the requirements for participating as either an exchange, a trader, or a miner. The course also covers other popular technology manifestations of blockchain, such as Hyperledger and Ripple. Dr. Reichental then puts blockchain technology in context in several different industries, including energy and security, and helps learners understand how to think about the blockchain in ways that can be applied in any field.
objectives: Explain how the relationship between blockchain and Bitcoin is similar to the relationship of the internet and FTP.
List specific qualities of a blockchain database.
Describe how transactions are updated in a distributed ledger.
Explain how the price of Bitcoin is derived.
Assess the core benefits of altcoins.
Recall how blockchain relates to the energy sector.
courses.comments:
A followup to this instructor's Blockchain Basics course.
Like that course, this one is a bit dated. He has a recent update to the prior course, but not yet for this one. But this course is still relevant, and most of the Blockchain-related Web sites he references still exist (although they may have evolved).

courses.title: Using Docker and .NET Core
courses.instructor: Shayne Boyer, Microsoft .NET , and Lisa Guthrie
courses.synopsis: Why use containers with your .NET Core applications? When you write an application, you have to consider the application code, frameworks, packages, and the underlying operating system itself. Using Docker allows you to encapsulate everything you need to run an application, with all its dependencies, in one nice, neat package that you can replicate on any machine or workstation, as many times as you need. In this course, Shayne Boyer and Lisa Guthrie start with the very basics of Docker, covering the concepts and practical uses, then move on to integrating Docker with Visual Studio to help you containerize your apps with just a few clicks. Finally, Shayne and Lisa show you a simple way to publish your containerized web app.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Dynamic Programming
courses.synopsis: Having a clearer picture of dynamic programming (DP) can take your coding to the next level. It's a technique that makes it possible to adeptly solve difficult problems, which is why it comes up in interviews and is used in applications like machine learning. In this course, learn about the uses of DP, how to determine when it’s an appropriate tactic, how it produces efficient and easily understood algorithms, and how it's used in real-world applications. Compare different approaches to computing the Fibonacci Sequence and learn how to visualize the problem as a directed acyclic graph. Explore the different variations of DP that you’re likely to encounter by working through a series of increasingly complex challenges. Plus, build a content-aware image resizing application with these new concepts at its core.
courses.comments:
I hadn't had the need to use Dynamic Programming techniques since learning about them at Cal State Fullerton. I find them interesting, so while taking this course, I dug up a couple of my text books from courses on algorithms from Fullerton, to refresh myself on what we learned there.
At Fullerton, we implemented some algorithms in C++, and in this course we used Python, so I was able to compare the differences in implementation between the two languages.
In this course, we coded a couple of DP algorithms to generate Fibonacci sequences, comparing their performance.
Along with solving a couple of other problems, we also implemented an application for content-aware image resizing, where instead of merely cropping an image, we removed "uninteresting" parts ("low energy" seams) from within an image.
I reworked our solution so that the program is called with a command line argument for the desired final percentage of the image width, rather than for how many low energy seams to remove, so that one doesn't need to know anything about the width in pixels of the original image.
We also implemented an application using the Viterbi algorithm with Hidden Markov Models to "predict" the next syllable, for use, for example, in speech recognition.

courses.title: UX Design: 7 Implementation Planning
courses.synopsis: User-centered design (UCD) artifacts aren't just for the visual aspect of design. In this final installment of "UX Design Techniques"—a series designed to teach you how to make your development process more user centered—learn how to use artifacts from each of the UCD techniques to help plan the implementation of your design.  Implementation planning happens at the end of the initial UCD cycle. First, you observe users, and then you create an experience map to extract pain points, goals, and personas. This gives you the information needed to do ideation exercises. After ideation, bring things back to reality by creating scenarios, which you use to build a prototype UI for planning purposes. By investing time in these UCD activities, you'll enter the development phase of your project with a much better understanding of what you need to build to delight your users. Having a set of measurable goals and a prototype interface makes it easier to plan your implementation and set interim deliverables that you know will deliver value to your users.
objectives: Prioritizing items on the story map
Setting metrics for story map items

courses.title: UX Design: 6 Paper Prototyping
courses.synopsis: In this installment of "UX Design Techniques," learn how to make paper prototypes so you can validate your ideas before you write any code. This method of prototyping is fast and inexpensive, allowing you to test design ideas early using simple materials: paper, Post-it notes, index cards, and Sharpies. Chris Nodder takes you through the process, including making separate sketches of each interface element, highlighting areas where there would be interaction between a system and a user, and then running through user testing so you can observe the user's experience, reposition elements, and make adjustments.
objectives: Testing using paper prototypes of interfaces

courses.title: UX Design: 5 Creating Scenarios and Storyboards
courses.synopsis: Scenarios and storyboards provide a reality check for your designs, helping you identify design gaps and articulate exactly what features you need to build to make users happy. This course shows how to use these tools to map the concepts generated during the ideation phase of UX design to a user's real-world tasks. Author Chris Nodder explains how to write scenarios and transform them into visual storyboards that show elements that are hard to describe with words alone, such as emotion, action, detail, and progression.  By the end, you'll have clear documentation to lead you through prototyping and implementation. Explore these phases and more in "UX Design Techniques" series on Chris's author page.

courses.title: UX Design: 4 Ideation
courses.synopsis: Ideation helps your team generate a lot of different design ideas in a short amount of time. In UX design, your first idea is seldom your best. A broad set of ideas is more likely to lead to a more creative, more satisfactory solution for your users. The ideation phase of UX design is where you consider all the different ways you could possibly fix your users' pain points, and then narrow down to some practical, viable alternatives.  In this installment of UX Design Techniques, Chris Nodder explores a variety of ideation techniques. Chris explains how to brainstorm in a way that lets all members of a team, not just the designers, contribute to a product's overall direction.

courses.title: Service Metrics for Customer Service
courses.synopsis: Establishing the right metrics to support effective customer service requires a solid understanding of how metrics work, how metrics are interrelated, and what the uses and limitations of metrics are. Wisely employed, the right metrics help guide decisions, support collaboration, and encourage better performance. But metrics that are incomplete, unfair, or misapplied can send the wrong messages, negatively impact customers and employees, and lead to inefficiencies.  This course covers, in a step-by-step fashion, why metrics are important, which metrics matter the most, how to interpret results, and examples of how successful organizations leverage metrics to improve decisions and performance. Whether your service operation includes face-to-face services, contact centers, social media, self-service, or any combination, this course provides practical know-how, real-life examples, and guidance for implementing and using the right metrics and establishing meaningful goals.
objectives: Essential metrics for the service operation
Engaging support that drives the right behaviors
Key areas of focus for individuals

courses.title: UX Design: 3 Creating Personas
courses.synopsis: Who are you developing for? How will they use your design? Building user personas can answer these important questions. In this course, Chris Nodder shows you how to create personas using information about the users most relevant to your business. He shows you how to gather and use data from interactions and site visits to define groups that represent a picture of your user types. These personas can help drive development and make sure your team is designing your product, application, or website with the same customer in mind, resulting in coherent, focused goals and an optimal user experience.

courses.title: UX Design: 2 Analyzing User Data
courses.synopsis: Who are your users? What are their challenges? How can your design solve their needs? UX research can help you answer these questions, and many more. In this installment of "UX Design Techniques," Chris Nodder walks through the process of acquiring user data and transforming that data into actionable project ideas. Learn how to observe users interacting with a prototype or simply performing tasks, build experience maps that depict those interactions, analyze the data, and extract ideas for new products and features.

courses.title: UX Design: 1 Overview
courses.synopsis: Following a user-centered design technique puts you more in touch with your users' true needs, which helps you develop solutions that really work for your intended audience. The approaches described in this course help development teams pool their diverse perspectives and collaborate to understand how to turn thoughts, feelings, frustrations, and desires of users into the design for a product.  Join Chris Nodder as he provides a road map to his series, "UX Design Techniques." Each technique in this series builds on the data and output from the previous techniques. The user data from observations is used to identify user pain points and create personas. The pain points and personas are used during the ideation phase to create multiple possible solutions. Scenarios and storyboards take these multiple possible solutions and narrow them down to a working set, from which you build a paper prototype that you can usability test with some more representative users. At any point, you can follow the trail all the way back to data you gathered from your initial observations.
objectives: Understanding the benefits of user-centered design

courses.title: Python Object-Oriented Programming
courses.synopsis: The object-oriented programming (OOP) features in Python make it easier to build programs of increasing complexity and modularity. In this course, you can learn how to apply core OOP principles like inheritance and composition along with some Python-specific features like “magic” methods and data classes to build programs that are extensible and efficient. Begin by brushing up on some object-oriented basics, and then use Python features like magic methods to make your classes integrate tightly with the Python language and data classes to dramatically reduce the amount of boilerplate code needed to build data-centric objects.

courses.title: Java Object-Oriented Programming
courses.synopsis: Are you familiar with Java but want to get the most out of your Java programs? In this course, Kathryn Hodge teaches the basics of object-oriented programming in Java, so you can write code that’s secure, scalable, and easier to troubleshoot. Kathryn begins by showing how object-oriented principles are embedded into the Java language from the first code file you create. She looks at how classes, instances, and constructors embody the idea of representing real-life objects in code. Kathryn not only shows how to apply object-oriented principles in your own programs, but also explains how Java leverages these principles behind the scenes. While many resources about object-oriented programming focus on abstract examples, the goal of this course is to get away from the abstract and focus more on practical examples of these principles in Java. Along with deep dives into the source code, this course also provides several challenges and solutions to help you apply what you’ve learned.
courses.comments:
I wanted a refresher on OOP with Java. I have more experience with OOP in C++, which unlike Java, allows for multiple inheritance.
We used the IntelliJ IDEA, and studied classes/objects, encapsulation and inheritance.
This course has a very good chapter on polymorphism, where we coded several examples, including both run-time and compile-time polymorphism.
There is also a very good chapter on abstraction, using interfaces, and abstract classes.
We also explored Java's own source code, to see how Java uses object-oriented programming behind the scenes.
Each chapter ends with a challenge/solution, demonstrating/implementing the concepts above.

courses.title: Introducing Maven
courses.synopsis: Apache Maven is a powerful build system used by thousands of Java developers on enterprise, freelance, and open-source projects. But it can do so much more. This course focuses on the basics of using Maven for dependency management, builds, and reporting. Instructor Frank Moley starts with the foundations: the project object model (POM) and POM elements, including properties and dependencies. He then reviews the build life cycle, showing how to leverage the Core and Tools plugins to automate tasks like cleanup and compile. He also shows how to manage dependencies, including creating uber JAR files to package executables with their dependencies. Finally, he covers reporting with Maven sites and popular plugins. By the end of the course, you should be familiar enough with Maven to use it to meet the needs of almost any Java project, from simple components to unique customized builds.
courses.comments:
I'd used Maven in Java projects in other courses I've taken here, but those were already-created projects, and although I did notice the project structure, I wasn't aware that it was a Maven thing, per se.
I was taking another course here where we created a Java/Maven project in the Eclipse IDE. We were led to making/modifying entries in the project's pom.xml file. Due to the age of that course, along with the differences between the versions used when the course was created and current versions, I ran into some issues matching up compatible versions/settings to use in the pom.xml file.
So I hoped that this course would help me figure out how to properly configure the pom.xml file used in the other course. It looks like it may do that, and I will try that now that I've learned some things in this course.

In this course, we did not create the Java/Maven project(s) from scratch, but (again) used/modified already-created projects. We did, however, learn about the various sections in the pom.xml file(s).
We used the IntelliJ IDEA here, and some student feedback in the other course I started mentioned that they had resorted to using IntelliJ instead of Eclipse, because the configuration was more straightforward. So I may find myself also resorting to using IntelliJ instead of Eclipse to finish that course.

courses.title: Customer Success Management Fundamentals
courses.synopsis: New to customer success management (CSM)? This course can help you get up to speed with the fundamentals. This course address what CSM is and why it's important; what types of situations CSM applies to; and how CSM can help increase a company’s sales revenues and profitability. The course then reviews the 14 tenets (or guiding principles) of customer success. Collectively, these tenets outline the role of the CSM in ensuring that customer success occurs and that its benefits are realized by both the CSM's own company and its customers. This course can be taken on its own as an introduction to the topic, or as one in a series of courses from PracticalCSM.com that build upon each other to cover the entirety of CSM best practices in greater detail.

courses.title: CSS: Display
courses.synopsis: Every CSS layout relies on the display property to tell it basic rules for how to present content. In this course, instructor Jen Kramer explains why the display property is so important and walks you through basic display values and newer display values that you need to understand to make effective use of this property. Jen discusses inline-level elements and the inline display value. She covers block-level elements, the block display value, and how to nest inline and block elements in HTML. Jen describes how to use “display: none” and “visibility: hidden” to hide content. Then she goes into newer display values, such as inline flex and grid values, the flow-root property, inline-block, tables, and list items. Jen concludes with recommendations on further HTM and CSS learning.
courses.comments:
Even more CSS training...
This turned out to be a good companion course to the Making Sense of the CSS Box Model course here that I completed before this one.
In this course, we used the CodePen site, where you can supply/modify HTML and CSS (and JavaScript, which we didn't use) and quickly see the results.

courses.title: Making Sense of the CSS Box Model
courses.synopsis: Based on old-school typography blocks, the CSS box model is the key to modern web design. Once you master it, you can build any layout you want—and troubleshoot most of the common CSS alignment and positioning woes. In this course, Morten Rand-Hendriksen offers a "four course meal" approach to the CSS box model, breaking it down into easily digestible chunks. He covers techniques such as styling text and images, floating content, using display properties, and positioning elements. He also explores the brave new world of modern layout modules, discussing Float, Flex, and Grid and how they can work together. Each lesson is supported by real-world demonstrations of the concepts in action, and Morten closes with a "nightcap" that will get you thinking about going further with CSS.
objectives: The origin of the box in typography
What is the CSS box model?
Changing the contents within the box
Working with Float, Flex, and Grid
courses.comments: More CSS training...

courses.title: Customer Service: Managing Customer Expectations
courses.synopsis: Today's customers expect a lot. Customer service expert Jeff Toister helps frontline employees identify where they can manage the expectations of customers to avoid upsetting them down the line. Specifically, how to avoid situations where unreasonable expectations might develop, and how to choose the right language to educate customers and explain potential areas of confusion. Despite your best efforts, customers may still develop inappropriate expectations, so Jeff also suggests tactics to counteract this problem. Finally, he provides tips for implementing the lessons learned in this course into your everyday customer service routine.

courses.title: Test Automation Foundations
courses.synopsis: Automated testing relies on scripting and frameworks like Selenium to prove that products work as expected. Test automation is an enormous time-saver, and it's crucial to continuous integration, continuous delivery, and agile software development. If you're employed in QA, DevOps, and IT, you need to know the basics. This course covers the foundations of test automation, as well as different strategies for implementation. QA engineer Meaghan Lewis explains what kinds of tests to use, how to choose the right test tools, and how to plan and execute test automation projects. She also describes strategies to maintain automation over time: adding new tests, updating old tests, and resolving failures.
objectives: Identifying the risks and cost of automation
courses.comments:
A foundations course that covers some of the same things covered in other courses here by this instructor, such as testing quadrants, the test pyramid, test types (unit, integration, and UI).
There wasn't much coding in this course, but for what there was, we coded in Node.js using the Atom text editor, and stored product data in MongoDB.
We ran the unit and integration tests from the terminal, and the UI tests using Selenium.
We learned about some Frameworks and Assertion libraries. We also learned how to configure and use Travis CI, tied into GitHub repositories.
And we learned how to decide what to automate, and used the Istanbul code coverage tool.

courses.title: Software Testing Foundations: Continuous Testing and DevOps
courses.synopsis: The next step beyond agile testing and test automation is continuous testing. Continuous testing means having your test automation run regularly and give code changes the green light before moving on in the development process. It can speed up the development life cycle and contribute to more stable and reliable software deliveries. DevOps provides you with the infrastructure to start running your automation in a continuous integration pipeline—this course can provide you with the skills. Join instructor and developer Jain Waldrip to learn the essential concepts of continuous testing and what DevOps means for QA. Discover methods for running automated tests in a continuous integration pipeline and explore common tools you will encounter in the process of implementing continuous testing. Jain also provides tips for running tests in containers and generating reports from your test results.

courses.title: Selenium Essential Training
courses.synopsis: Take your Selenium framework skills to the next level. In this course, Meaghan Lewis takes you past the basics covered in Learning Selenium, on to intermediate and advanced options. First, Meaghan reviews the fundamentals and shows you how to get the most out of WebDriver. Next, she takes you into the mechanics of advanced locators and interacting with components. Then she shares how to overcome common synchronization issues. She wraps up by covering workflows and integrations.
courses.comments:
This is a longer companion/follow-up course expanding on this instructor's Learning Selenium course here.
We coded in Java (instead of in Ruby) this time, using the IntelliJ IDEA, and we installed and used ChromeDriver, instead of GeckoDriver, which we used for Firefox in the prior course.
We created tests against pages at FORMY.
As in the prior course, we progressed from coding a series of statements for testing a Web page app, to cleaning up the code by extracting those statements into functions, then broke those functions out into Java Classes, to conform to the Page Object Pattern.
We then created a Git Repository locally, and remotely on GitHub, then pushed our code to GitHub.
The instructor finished up by introducing us to various CI (Continuous Integration) servers, and the Sauce Labs cloud-based testing tool.

courses.title: Docker on AWS
courses.synopsis: Docker is the next step beyond virtualization. When deployed with Amazon Elastic Container Service (AWS ECS), you have a solid foundation for monitoring and managing Docker containers, including starting containers and scheduling tasks. This frees up developers to concentrate on your container-based applications—instead of your hosting platform. In this course, Robert Starmer demonstrates how to use Docker and the powerful features in AWS to build and manage container-based applications. Learn how to create containerized applications, set up AWS ECS, mange container scale and network models, troubleshoot issues, and more.
objectives: Configuring ECS for EC2 and Fargate
Adding an ECS service and task

courses.title: Learning NuGet
courses.synopsis: This course is an introduction to NuGet, the official package manager for .NET. Packages are essentially compiled libraries packed together with descriptive metadata into an easily shareable unit, meaning NuGet lets developers leverage a massive ecosystem and utilize existing solutions as a foundation instead of building everything from scratch.  Instructor Christopher Gill covers NuGet essentials like package management, the tools and resources NuGet provides, and how to use those tools to leverage and contribute to the extensive .NET ecosystem. He also covers the ins and outs of NuGet.org, the central repository for .NET developers to find and publish .NET packages.
courses.comments:
I'd had to research and then use NuGet to get things working in Visual Studio for the ASP.NET Web Forms Essential Training course I took here. This course provided a good overall view on what NuGet is all about.

We covered installing and using a NuGet package with Visual Studio, and with the .NET CLI, after using Visual Studio Code for the coding.
We also created and published a NuGet package to nuget.org with Visual Studio, and with the .NET CLI, after using Visual Studio Code for the coding.

courses.title: AWS Security Best Practices for Developers
courses.synopsis: Security matters to everyone, but solid security practices start with the developer of an application. In this developer-centered course, instructor and AWS Certified Solutions Architect Carlos Rivas shows how to build stronger, more secure applications for deployment on Amazon Web Services. Learn core AWS security development principles around Identity and Access Management (IAM), S3 storage, and Key Management Service (KMS), to ensure your users, systems, and data are secure on the cloud. Plus, learn how to use Cognito to establish user identity without maintaining unique login credentials for each application.
objectives: S3 security policies, encryption, and version control

courses.title: Learning Selenium
courses.synopsis: Selenium is one of the most popular tools for testing web-based applications. It allows QA engineers to write and automate tests across many different browsers and operating systems, without a special scripting language. This course introduces Selenium to new users, covering installation and basic use cases. Find out how to set up the test-writing framework, WebDriver, and Selenium Grid, which allows you to distribute the testing load and run tests against a remote server. Learn best practices to write effective tests using variables and functions, and to organize tests into suites that can scale over time. Instructor Meaghan Lewis—a QA engineer at GitHub—also explains the test pyramid paradigm, which details an ideal way to balance unit, integration, and UI testing.
objectives: Distributing the testing load with Selenium grid
Setting up a hub and nodes
courses.comments:
A good starting course about using Selenium for automating testing on Web page apps —
We installed and used Ruby to code the tests, using the Sublime Text text editor. It was good for me to get some more Ruby practice.
We installed the Selenium WebDriver and the RSpec Ruby Gem.
We also installed and used Selenium Grid, setting up the hub and configuring nodes, to distribute and run tests against remote browser instances.
And we learned about the Page Object Pattern, creating classes for each page of a Web page app.

courses.title: Programming Foundations: Software Testing/QA
courses.synopsis: Quality assurance (QA) engineering can mean many different things to different people. In this course, learn about QA practices within the context of a software engineering project. Instructor Meaghan Lewis demonstrates the different kinds of testing QA focuses on and how QA fits into the software development life cycle (SDLC). Meaghan explores the areas you'll likely want to test and continuously monitor to ensure increasing improvements to your product. Plus, she goes over some of the mechanisms used to communicate the overall health of a product. Upon wrapping up this course, you'll be able to look at whatever you're working on, think critically about how the pieces fit together, and identify ways to help your team meet quality goals with every release.
objectives: How QA fits into the software development life cycle (SDLC)
Incorporating box testing into your process

courses.title: Improve Cognitive Flexibility at Work
courses.synopsis: The ability to switch mental gears quickly and efficiently isn't just a boon for workers needing to pivot after a setback. This facility—also known as cognitive flexibility—is critical to everyone’s mental and physical health. Employees of all stripes need the ability to pivot, adapt, and challenge their automatic assumptions in order to increase their adaptability, resilience, and creativity. In this course, clinical psychologist and best-selling author Andrea Bonior teaches science-backed techniques for improving cognitive flexibility. Discover how to build daily mental habits to increase adaptability and clear-thinking, as well as practice incorporating innovation into your daily life. Tune in to nudge yourself beyond your comfort zone and learn how to build and maintain cognitive flexibility over the long term.
courses.comments: I saw that a former coworker, who frequently finds interesting, informative courses here, had taken this one.

courses.title: Statistics Foundations: 2
courses.synopsis: Statistics are a core skill for many careers. Basic stats are critical for making decisions, new discoveries, investments, and even predictions. But sometimes you need to move beyond the basics. Statistics Fundamentals – Part 2 takes business users and data science mavens into practical, example-based learning of the intermediate skills associated with statistics: samples and sampling, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing.  Eddie Davila first provides a bridge from Part 1, reviewing introductory concepts such as data and probability, and then moves into the topics of sampling, random samples, sample sizes, sampling error and trustworthiness, the central unit theorem, t-distribution, confidence intervals (including explaining unexpected outcomes), and hypothesis testing. This course is a must for those working in data science, business, and business analytics—or anyone else who wants to go beyond means and medians and gain a deeper understanding of how statistics work in the real world.
objectives: List the three primary issues addressed in Statistics Foundations: 2.
Recognize two key characteristics associated with simple random samples.
Apply the Central Limit Theorem to find the average of sample means.
Analyze random samples during hypothesis testing.
Assess individual situations to determine whether a one-tailed or two-tailed test is necessary.
courses.comments:
Yet another one in my run of Statistics refresher courses here.
We covered sampling, sample size (and the effects it has), and confidence intervals.
And we finished up with a whole chapter on Hypothesis Testing, which was really good, since we did it repeatedly, which drilled the process in.

courses.title: Learning R
courses.synopsis: If you want to participate in the data revolution, you need the right tools and skills. R is a free, open-source language for data science that is among the most popular platforms for professional analysts. Learn the basics of R and get started finding insights from your own data, in this course with professor and data scientist Barton Poulson. The lessons explain how to get started with R, including installing R, RStudio, and code packages that extend R’s power. You also see first-hand how to use R and RStudio for beginner-level data modeling, visualization, and statistical analysis. By the end of the course, you’ll have a thorough introduction to the power and flexibility of R, and understand how to leverage this tool to explore and analyze a wide variety of data.
objectives: Visualizing data with R base graphics and ggplot2
courses.comments:
A good companion starting course to the R Programming in Data Science: Setup and Start course I took earlier here for R.
We got into the language a bit more than in that prior course, but we didn't get into loops, conditionals, etc., mainly just using statements for manipulating/processing dataframes.
The instructor gave us a tour of RStudio (which we used throughout the course), including some of the settings.
We used the pacman package manager package to load and unload packages, and as in the earlier course, we also used the tidyverse package, which among other things, provides the handy piping command.
We also covered data visualization, data wrangling, and data analysis.

courses.title: Learning Network Troubleshooting
courses.synopsis: Troubleshooting network issues is a key skill for a wide range of IT professionals and network professionals. In this course, instructor Robert McMillen teaches you the skills and tools that you need to start network troubleshooting. Robert begins with an overview on how to triage network problems, including basic TCP/IP issues and causes, then steps you through some common home networking and wireless issues. He covers the most common issues with corporate wireless networks and how to troubleshoot Wi-Fi interference. Robert explains different types of VPN, common errors you may encounter, and how to fix them. After showing you some network tools that administrators need to know, he discusses how to fix problems you may run into with routing, switching, and firewalls.
courses.comments:
I wanted a refresher on using Wireshark and Fiddler, so I looked here for videos and/or courses on them.
I saw that there was a video on Wireshark in this course, and that the rest of this course would also be a good refresher for me, so I completed it.
I already knew a lot of it, but appreciated being reminded. And I hadn't much used the PowerShell cmdlets. It was nice that the instructor compared them to their command line counterparts, pointing out differences between them.
I also wasn't familiar with most of what we learned in the chapter on VPNs.
And the lesson/video on Wireshark was good - we used Nmap/Zenmap on the "black hat" computer to scan to the "white hat" computer, where we used Wireshark to peruse what was scanned. It was good to get refreshed on this, since it's been a while since I used it.
We used the Windows Defender Firewall in the Troubleshooting open firewall ports lesson, which was also a good refresher for me, since I'd more recently used the McAfee Firewall to control ports.

courses.title: R Programming in Data Science: Setup and Start
courses.synopsis: R is powerful, but not intuitive. There is a strong and diverse R ecosystem, and data scientists are expected to mix and match from the different versions and packages. Before you can even begin programming, you have to choose, install, and set up R to work for you.  In this course, Mark Niemann-Ross provides a direct and efficient introduction to the many flavors of the R programming language, including base R, tidyverse R, R Open from Microsoft, and Bioconductor R. He also provides a peek at programming with R interactively and via the command line, and introduces some helpful packages for working with SQL, 3D graphics, data, and clusters in R. At the end of this short course, you will have installed a version of R along with a few core libraries and an optimized IDE.
objectives: Explain why Base R is a unique programming language.
Summarize how to install R for Macintosh, Windows, Linux, or Unix.
Name the IDE that does not have support for R.
Describe two ways to set up R Tools for Visual Studio.
Identify the three ways R programs can be executed.
List two functions that sqldf adds to Base R.
courses.comments:
This is a good starting course for R, as it covers different versions/flavors of R - what is unique about that version, installing/using it, and what IDE is recommended for that version.
We mainly used the RStudio IDE, with the main exception being using Visual Studio for Microsoft Open R. We also used R Tools for Visual Studio, but since Microsoft changed how R is implemented in VS 2019, I had problems opening the provided Solution/Project files, and ended up just opening the R source code files themselves.
We covered the same task in the different versions, to see how the coding differed between them, and also a task that was optimal for each particular version.
We covered using R interactively, and from the command line, with arguments, and finished up with common R packages:
* sqldf
* rgl — for 3D plots - interactive, and with animations!
* data.table — streamlined syntax
* cluster

courses.title: Statistics Foundations: Probability
courses.synopsis: Not sure if you need statistics? Think again! Statistics help with making decisions, new discoveries, investments, and predictions. For subjects ranging from political races to healthcare advancements, statistics can improve your understanding of your favorite topic. In this course, Professor Eddie Davila teaches common terms, formulas, and techniques related to probability, the area of statistics where this course focuses.  Eddie explains that probability is used to make decisions about future outcomes and to understand past outcomes. He covers permutations, combinations, and percentiles, and goes into how to describe and calculate them. Eddie introduces multiple event probabilities and discusses when to add and subtract probabilities. He describes probability trees, Bayes’ Theorem, binomials, and so much more. You can learn to understand your data, prove theories, and save valuable resources—all by understanding the numbers.
courses.comments:
Another one in my run of Statistics refresher courses here.
This was a good course for me - the Chapter Quizzes made me calculate, and...think!
We covered permutations and combinations, for determining possible outcomes.
We also covered Probability Trees, for multiple events, and Bayes Theorem (for doing away with drawing the trees).
When discussing normal and bell-shaped curves, we stopped short of using Calculus to calculate the area under a curve, as of course we did in my Statistics course at CSUF, but were still able to estimate for ranges.

courses.title: Customer Service Foundations
courses.synopsis: Do your customers feel valued? When they do, they keep coming back. When they don't, your business suffers. In this course, writer and customer service consultant Jeff Toister teaches you the three crucial skill sets needed to deliver outstanding customer service and increase customer loyalty. Learn how to build winning relationships, provide the right assistance at the right times, and effectively handle angry customers. He also shares ways to find out what your customers really think about your service, and use their feedback to improve.
objectives: Explore how you can use customer surveys to build rapport.
Name three ways you can use active listening to serve your customers more effectively.
Identify the different types of needs that must be addressed in order to solve problems.
Explain the benefits of taking ownership of a problem.
Define “preemptive acknowledgment” and recognize its impact on customer service.
List three types of attitude anchors and explain their differences.
courses.comments:
I saw that multiple former co-workers had taken this course. That made me think that maybe it was evaluation-time there. ;^) Or that their manager had directed them to take this course. (Or both/neither?)
This course would be great for someone starting out in Customer Service, but is also good for those with plenty of experience. This excellent instructor, who has several great courses on Customer Service here on LinkedIn Learning, provides good tips and techniques, which can also serve as good reminders for even those experienced with Customer Service.

courses.title: Statistics Foundations: The Basics
courses.synopsis: Statistics is not just the realm of data scientists. All types of jobs use statistics. Statistics are important for making decisions, new discoveries, investments, and predictions. Whether the subject is political races, sports rankings, shopping trends, or healthcare advancements, statistics is an instrument for understanding your favorite topic at a deeper level. In this course, Professor Eddie Davila offers beginner-level lessons, so you too can master the terms, formulas, and techniques needed to perform the most common types of statistics.  Eddie covers several examples of data and charts. He explains how to find the middle of your data set, as well as the mean and median. He introduces range, then goes into standard deviation and what to do with outliers. These techniques help you understand your data, prove theories, and save time, money, and other valuable resources—all by understanding the numbers.
courses.comments:
It's been years since my Statistics course at CSU Fullerton, where I had an excellent professor (Dr. Hromodka).
So I thought that I could use some refresher Statistics courses from here at LinkedIn Learning, of which this is my first.
I remembered most of the things covered, such as the mean, median, mode, range and standard deviation.
I didn't quite remember the Z-Score (I remembered what it was, but had forgotten the name) and the Empirical Rule (I recalled the gist of it, but not the specifics).

courses.title: Learning Amazon Web Services Lambda
courses.synopsis: Ready to go serverless? Learn the essentials of working with AWS Lambda, a compute service that handles administration for you, so you're only responsible for your code. In this course, Marcia Villalba helps beginners get up and running with Lambda. To begin, she explains the basics of securing an AWS account and creating IAM users. From there, she moves on to the main concepts of the Lambda programming model and shows how to create Lambda functions and add API Gateway as a trigger. She steps through how to do everything from the AWS console to solidify your baseline knowledge before showing how to create lambda functions with the AWS Serverless Application Framework (SAM), which uses the paradigm of infrastructure as code—the recommended way to develop serverless applications.
objectives: Add API Gateway as a trigger to Lambda
courses.comments:
An excellent course!
I've used AWS Lambda in other courses here, but this is a course dedicated to that (although we did use API Gateway, and other AWS services as well).
We used IAM, creating a non-Root user with Admin privileges to use in this course.
We created a Lambda function (using Node.js) with an API Gateway Trigger, and used Postman for testing the API.
We learned about "infrastructure as code," and then then we installed the AWS Serverless Application Model (SAM) Framework and the SAM CLI, using it to package another application (another Lambda function with an API Gateway) with CloudFormation, and then deploy it.
We then added another Lambda function with an API Gateway to that app, and redeployed it to the same S3 bucket where it resided, using the SAM CLI.
Repeating this process a few times helped to drill it in for me.

courses.title: Customer Service: Serving Customers Through Chat and Text
courses.synopsis: Customers are demanding more ways to connect with companies when they need help. Live chat and text are the fastest growing and most popular channels. While you may be a pro at writing emails, you need a whole new set of skills to handle live, rapid-fire chat and text conversations. You’ll need to be able to handle multiple conversations at one time, and may even be required to sell or recommend products. This course walks through each of these situations, and more, using real-world chats and texts. Instructor Leslie O’Flahavan also explains how to incorporate templates and empathy statements and add your own authentic spin—all while maintaining your company’s brand. Learn all the writing skills you’ll need to provide top-notch live chat and text customer service.
objectives: Writing in your company’s brand voice
courses.comments:
While composing hypothetical Support responses for an assessment that I was taking while looking for a new position, I may have tended too much towards an email style, instead of the chat/text style that was expected(?). (It was a bit hard to tell from the given scenarios, because the questions just used the word "message." And since I was also expected to base my replies on the company's documentation, it seemed that shorter replies (as expected in a chat/text channel), would not have demonstrated that. It was a bit confusing. (Suffice it to say - I did not advance to the next step...)
I hadn't used chat/text in a Support role (except with internal customers), so I thought that I should get up to speed.
So now, if it's clear that I'm in a chat/text situation, I am better prepared.

This instructor provided good advice, and as a side-effect, also taught me how to better uphold my end of the chat/text when I'M the one seeking assistance.

courses.title: Vue.js for Web Designers
courses.synopsis: Vue.js is a popular JavaScript framework that can be used to build interactive components or entire single-page apps. It's a powerful and flexible framework for the modern web designer—whether you use a little of it or a lot. In this course, Joe Chellman offers practical ways to incorporate Vue.js in real-world web designs. He introduces three small projects that benefit from Vue: a real-time updating product customizer that shows how to manage data and respond to events with Vue; an employee directory using Vue forms and animation; and a status board that makes external API calls and uses a third-party Vue component. Each project demonstrates what makes Vue most interesting and useful to web designers and provides solutions for dealing with the few unique challenges.
objectives: Incorporating live data via REST APIs
courses.comments:
We installed the Vue.js devtools extension in Chrome and Firefox, and I also installed a beta extension for Edge.
We then worked on 3 projects:
- Customizer, for sneaker shopping - select a size and a color, and the sneaker image changes color and size.
- Directory Browser, for browsing and searching a personnel directory, with live search and filtering.
and
- Status Updater, for posting various types of update messages to a hotel's Web site.
This project used MySQL via a PHP Web site, and Axios, a promise-based HTTP Client.
We finished up by adding a third-party Vue component (vue-simple-spinner).

Now that I've taken first courses on 3 popular JavaScript frameworks (React, Angular, and now Vue) and liked working with all of them, I can go forth and take follow-up courses. I'm hoping that another Angular course will help me with my modifications to the Media Watch List app that we did in the Angular Essential Training course here, that I'm adding to for my own use.
I've also started modifying the Directory Browser app from this course, for another presentation of my LinkedIn Learning courses data.

courses.title: Software Design: Modeling with UML
courses.synopsis: Modeling with the Unified Modeling Language (UML)—a visual design language for object-oriented programming—is a critical skill for all team members in a software development project. These models are a cost-effective way for collaborators to analyze, communicate, and document their product's characteristics. In this course, learn how to use UML diagrams to create important artifacts at each stage of the software development life cycle. Instructor Neelam Dwivedi shares best practices and tools as she goes over 13 different types of UML models, explaining what you need to know to develop static and dynamic models of software systems.
objectives: How UML differs from other modeling techniques
Use case, activity, and class diagrams
Capturing real-time state of your system in action
courses.comments:
I saw a job posting that mentioned UML, so thought that I should learn about it...
The instructor covered 13 types of UML models, their key components and the notations.
I've used Visio, but since I don't have it now, I downloaded the PlantUML.jar file, and installed Graphviz, setting its Environment Variable, so that I could use PlantUML (a tool for creating diagrams from a plain text language) from the Command Line, as well as from MS Word.
I added a PlantUML Word Add-In Template file, placing it and PlantUML.jar in the Word STARTUP folder.
I also added a PlantUML Extension to VS Code.

courses.title: XML Essential Training
courses.synopsis: Extensible Markup Language (XML) was designed to make information sharing and data interpretation easier. Having a solid grasp of what XML is and how to work with it is essential for any developer. In this course, Joe Marini takes you through the basic rules of XML, explains its syntax, and covers more advanced topics such as styling your XML with CSS and manipulating XML content using XPath and XSLT. From integrating XML into your site to using document type definitions and XML schema, this course covers what you need to know to not only get started with XML, but also master it.
objectives: Manipulating XML content using XPath and XSLT
Document type definitions and XML schema
courses.comments:
Another refresher course, but it included some new things for me, such as styling XML code with XSLT and CSS - I had only used XML as straight data, either from/to Web APIs, or for software configuration, or in Custom Modules (for Ascent/Kofax Capture).
We manipulated XML with the DOM, using JavaScript.
We also learned about XPath, and about enforcing rules and constraints on XML data with Document Type Definitions (DTDs), and XML Schema. We used an online tool to validate our XML data against a DTD and against an XML Schema, at Validate XML files.

courses.title: Customer Service: Problem Solving and Troubleshooting
courses.synopsis: Customer service care costs organizations billions of dollars each year. As a result, it's critical that employees are equipped with the skills needed to handle a variety of different customer service problems. In this course, learn critical problem-solving and troubleshooting processes for common sense customer service in a wide variety of applications. Discover how to effectively deal with issues, while maintaining a positive relationship with your customers (and your own sanity). Plus, learn how to identify and resolve larger systemic issues within your company.
objectives: Identify the first step to take with an invalid complaint.
Recognize the importance of always listening to the customer.
Explain how to deal with a customer who is rude and making you uncomfortable.
courses.comments:
This instructor puts a lot of emphasis on judging whether a customer's complaint is valid or invalid. (And then he DOES expand on how to deal with BOTH kinds.)
In my support roles, I'd have to say that the vast majority of complaints, or more likely, issues/problems, were in fact valid, and thus, mostly assumed to be.
However, many years ago, I did work at a hotel (in a public-facing role), where a greater percentage of the complaints were in fact invalid, so I do understand the need for such an initial judgement in some scenarios.

courses.title: ASP.NET Web Forms Essential Training
courses.synopsis: Web Forms are a simple way to build web pages. In this course, discover how to build simple Web Forms applications in ASP.NET. Instructor Tiberiu Covaci shows how to create your first Web Forms page, debug it, create reusable code, and work with data. After stepping through how to create your first Visual Studio project, he shows how to work with Web Forms controls, shares tips for writing maintainable code, and covers different options for debugging ASP.NET applications. To wrap up, he discusses how to work with data and Microsoft SQL Server.
objectives: Working with ASP.NET Web Forms controls
courses.comments:
A good refresher course for me -
I hadn't taken an ASP.NET course in a decade, and haven't dug into the code (for the ASP.NET/SQL Server-based Support Knowledge Base that I managed) for more than a couple of years.
The instructor went over creating a Web Forms page, and the lifecycle of an ASP.NET page.
We covered debugging and tracing, and also exception handling. The instructor was too brief, in my opinion, on exception handling, and I'll give him a "C" on that part. (Fortunately, I've had prior good instruction and experience on/with this topic.)
We learned about creating Web Controls, exposing public properties of them, and registering and using them.
In the Working with Data chapter, the instructor used a LocalDB SQL Server database, but I wanted to use my own SQL Server instance. So I attached the provided database files to my SQL Server, and used Connection Strings to that. I had to fiddle with the Application Pool settings in IIS to use Integrated Security for the database access, so I decided to create a new Application Pool for the app and used that. But I also created a database user (using SQL Server Authentication), granting it the minimum rights necessary, and created a Connection String for that user. I then coded the app both ways (to be able to use either user).
We finished up with adding our User (Web) Control to the ListView (that we used to display the data), using it to insert and update data (instead of the built-in functionality).

courses.title: Learning Amazon Web Services (AWS) for Developers
courses.synopsis: Amazon Web Services (AWS) is the leading cloud service provider today, ahead of competitors such as Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud Platform. It is seen by many as the standard for functional, reliable, interoperable, and affordable cloud services. Developers need to understand what it means to develop on and migrate to the cloud—and comprehend the overall landscape of AWS before diving into the platform. This course provides a high-level overview just for developers, focusing on the AWS features and services of the most interest to them. Instructor Bear Cahill introduces AWS Lambda, DynamoDB, ElastiCache, Elastic Beanstalk, S3, SQS, SNS, and many more key features and services.
objectives: Setting up security: users, roles, groups, and policies
Adding storage with S3 and DynamoDB
courses.comments:
A good course that surveys many of the AWS services that a developer would use.
We covered Security - Users, Permissions, Roles, etc. using IAM. We also learned about Cognito (which I hadn't used before) for Identity and User Pools.
As in other courses I have taken here, we used Lambda - this time we created one using a blueprint. We also used the Simple Queue Service (SQS) and the Simple Notification Service (SNS), configuring them to communicate with each other and the Lambda. And we created a DynamoDB Trigger to our Lambda.
We used CloudWatch - for checking logs, and for setting alarms for such things as latency above a certain threshold, for costs, etc.
We also learned about Elastic Beanstalk, CloudFormation, ElastiCache, and CloudFront.
And we finished up with the instructor leading us through how to clean up by deleting all of the things we built in AWS for this course.

courses.title: Advanced Pandas
courses.synopsis: If you've worked in Python, you're likely familiar with the basic of pandas. In this advanced course, instructor Brett Vanderblock shares how you can take advantage of the advanced functions of pandas—such as working with dates, dealing with missing data, merging DataFrames, and more—to work more effectively with your data. First, Brett introduces you to DataFrames, identifies the top functions in pandas, and shows you how to configure your pandas workspace efficiently. He walks you through converting data types, working with strings, and using the apply map and applymap functions effectively. He shows you how to combine Groupby and multiple aggregate functions in pandas and how to use the merge, join, and concat functions. Brett steps through plotting and statistical functions with pandas. He concludes by explaining how you can use pandas-profiling and Geopandas to get the most out of your functions and data.  This course was created by Madecraft. We are pleased to host this training in our library.
courses.comments:
This course used the Jupyter Notebook platform.
I got some more practice with stack and unstack, and learned about functions I hadn't used, such as pivot, pivot_table, and melt.
We learned about merging, joining and concatenating dataframes, as well as categorizing and correlation.
I learned more about plotting, and pandas Profiling, which is a nice tool.
We also used geopandas - We had to go to mapbox's site for a free API token, then we turned our dataframe consisting of location names and latitude and longitude values into a GeoDataFrame, creating an interactive map (using plotly) showing the locations of 5 mountain peaks west of Boulder, CO.

courses.title: PostgreSQL Essential Training
courses.synopsis: PostgreSQL is one of the world’s most popular open-source database platforms. This highly flexible and scalable relational database management system (RDBMS) supports everything from general purpose databases to machine learning applications and geospatial map servers. In this course, instructor Adam Wilbert helps you get up and running with PostgreSQL. Adam covers the essential first steps of setting up a PostgreSQL server and working with the graphical interface, pgAdmin. He then shows how to work with pgAdmin to create new database objects, populate them with data, and retrieve records from the database. If you're new to the platform (or relational databases in general), this course serves as an entry point and provides a solid foundation for further exploration in database administration.
courses.comments:
I used a containerized (using Docker) PostgreSQL database in the Learning JDBC course I took here, and I also used that in a Data Engineering Foundations course (also here).
After the latter course, I decided that it was time to take this course, that I had queued up after the former course.
I had taken a sneak peek at this course because it has a lesson about using a graphical interface, so I had gone ahead and installed pgAdmin 4 and used it with the containerized PostgreSQL database in both of those earlier courses.
In this course, we installed PostgreSQL locally (not in a container), and the installation also included pgAdmin 4. I went ahead and used my prior installation of it, since I had recently updated it (to a newer version than was included in this local installation).
In this local installation, I had taken care to specify a different port than was used in the container, to avoid conflicts. And pgAdmin 4 still showed the server in the container (running or not), and when I connected to this new (local) server, I was able to see and use both.
As with other "Essential..." courses here, this course started out very basic, in this case, regarding SQL and relational database concepts such as foreign keys, and joins, etc. It did pick up, and we got into constraints and indexes, accounts, roles and privileges, and backing up and restoring databases.
I mostly appreciated being reminded of the differences in the flavor of SQL used here and other flavors I have used, as well as learning more about what is available in pgAdmin 4 and how it works.

courses.title: Creativity at Work: A Short Course from Seth Godin
courses.synopsis: You are a creative person. Despite what your inner critic may have told you, you absolutely can solve complex business problems without a roadmap. The potential is there; whether or not you tap into it is up to you. In this concise course, Seth Godin—the author of 20 best-selling books, including The Dip, Linchpin, Purple Cow, and The Practice—lays out how to help your team let go of the fears that hinder your creative progress and start creating work that matters. Learn how to combat preconceived notions about creativity, including the idea that creativity is a gift bestowed upon a select few. (Spoiler alert: it's not.) Discover how to tap into your team’s creativity by embracing the possibility of failure, cultivating practical empathy, and exploring the root causes of writer's block and impostor syndrome. Plus, get tips for making creative problem-solving a habit that sticks.
courses.comments: The instructor has very interesting and out-of-the-ordinary ways of looking at some things.

courses.title: Data Engineering Foundations
courses.synopsis: Data science can be generally defined as the process of making data useful, and data engineering is a key part of how and why. If you think of data science like a race car, the data engineers are the pit crew. They’re not driving the car, but they make the car much easier to drive. Data engineers make sure the data flow is running smoothly, monitor systems, anticipate problems, and repair the data pipeline whenever problems arise. They extract and gather data from multiple sources and load it into a single, easy-to-query database. In short, data engineers make data scientists’ lives easier.  In this course, Harshit Tyagi explains the fundamentals of data engineering. He covers key topics like data wrangling, database schema, and developing ETL pipelines. He also details several data engineering tools like Hive, Hadoop, Spark, and Airflow. By the end of this course, it should be abundantly clear why the data engineer is one of the most valuable people in a data-driven organization.

courses.title: AWS for Developers: DynamoDB
courses.synopsis: DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database solution hosted on the AWS cloud. It allows developers quickly scale to support millions of requests without having to worry about provisioning, clustering, patching, and replication. DynamoDB is also known for being an ideal solution for web APIs due to its robust support of JSON. In this course, learn how to leverage this solution so you can reap the high-performance benefits. Robby Millsap covers planning, database fundamentals, coding, and support. He takes you through the process of modeling data, creating tables, using Node.js, indexing, fetching, searching, scanning, querying, authentication, monitoring, and more.
objectives: Working with composite keys and sort keys
courses.comments:
An excellent course!

After I took the Angular Essential Training course here, I saw an article about hosting an Angular app on GitHub, then I also discovered that there is on issue with GitHub Pages with Angular apps that use Routing. I found some articles about getting around those issues, but for the time being I settled with just hosting the project from the course, with some of my own modifications (with more to come), on my local Apache and IIS Web servers.
After taking the Building Serverless Apps on AWS course here, I stored the Angular app in an S3 bucket, and it worked.
In that Angular project, we used a mock API back end, and didn't persist the data, but after taking that Building Serverless Apps on AWS course, I foresaw using a DynamoDB database and an API Gateway for the Angular project. So I thought that I needed to learn more about DynamoDB databases, and this course definitely fit the bill.

We covered data modeling for maximum performance, and cost considerations, as well as installing and using the AWS CLI, scanning and querying data.
We also covered coding to the database using Node.js - to create a table, insert data (also using transactions) and query the data.
We learned about and enabled Streams, to track when data was changed and what the changes were and coded a script to output that info.
We also installed and used DynamoDB locally, so as not to rack up charges on AWS while developing.
The table that the instructor had us create was pretty cool, dealing with a small bit of baseball team stats, and mostly focusing on the Angels.

courses.title: Building Serverless Apps on AWS
courses.synopsis: Learn how to develop a NodeJS serverless app on Amazon Web Services (AWS). First, get introduced to several services: Lambda, DynamoDB, S3, Postman, and the API gateway. Then, see how to install Postman, set up an Amazon account, implement an S3 storage bucket with static content, and set up serverless Lambda compute. Next, find out how to create a table on the DynamoDB AWS service and create a POST function. Additionally, discover how to code and test final endpoint functions.
objectives: Setting up a base client app
courses.comments:
Although the Serverless and Microservices for AWS course I took here was good, with the instructor explaining the architecture and the decision-making when implementing, and transitioning an existing application to AWS, we didn't actually DO any of it. So I got a feel for what the pieces were, and how they fit together, but not how each piece actually worked.
In THIS course, we actually USED some of the AWS services -
