We put a static Web site up in an S3 storage bucket, and set the permissions appropriately. So I then put up my LinkedIn Learning Courses Web site that I have on GitHub onto AWS (Courses on AWS).
We set up a table in DynamoDB, and wrote some Lambda compute functions for POST and GET to/from it, and tested those functions in Lambda. We then set up an API Gateway for those functions, and tested our API externally using Postman.
This course also had some issues with being a little old - the Node.js versions available on AWS had changed some, so that we had to modify the provided code a bit. Other students helped out with this in the Q&A section. And the AWS interface had changed, so I had to poke around a bit to find the current location of a key setting to get my Lambda compute functions to work.
As always, if any of you take this course and need help with those two issuess, I am happy to help...

courses.title: Build a Google Maps App with JavaScript
courses.synopsis: Build a quick and compelling app that uses the Google Places library and JavaScript to implement geolocation. In this short, hands-on course, Mark Lassoff helps you create a simple Google Maps integrated application using vanilla JavaScript: Feed Me, a restaurant locator. This project can help you hone your JavaScript skills and add a much-needed feature—an interactive map—to your existing sites and applications. Plus, learn how to add extra information to Google Maps markers, such as the price and rating for the featured restaurants.  This course was created by Framework Tech. We are pleased to host this training in our library.
courses.comments:
A refresher for me of the content of some other courses I've taken here that covered mapping -
I'm disappointed that Google no longer supports keyless use of the Google Maps API, and since I didn't want to go through the rigmarole of registering for an API Key, and providing credit card info, etc., I wasn't able to use all of the features used in our app. But enough to follow along with, and learn a few things. For instance, the instructor clued me in to Sensors in a Web browser's Web Developer Tools, where one can change the Location, for testing, and the Device Toolbar, where one can test out the display for various mobile devices.

courses.title: Angular Essential Training
courses.synopsis: Angular was designed by Google to address challenges programmers face building complex, single-page applications. This JavaScript platform provides a solid core of web functionality, letting you take care of the design and implementation details. In this course, Justin Schwartzenberger introduces you to the essentials of this "superheroic" platform, including powerful features such as two-way data binding, comprehensive routing, and dependency injection. Justin steps through the platform one feature at a time, focusing on the component-based architecture of Angular. Learn what Angular is and what it can do, as Justin builds a full-featured web app from start to finish. After mastering the essentials, you can tackle the other project-based courses in our library and create your own Angular app.
courses.comments:
Angular is a very complex client-side framework for JavaScript, but is very powerful, and it actually makes some things simpler to manage.
We learned about creating Components, using Angular Forms (using built-in and custom validation) along with HTTP calls and Routing (to different (API) URLs).
We used the Web Developer Tools in a Web browser to see what Angular turned into the page's HTML, to help understand what Angular is doing, and we finished up with a whole chapter on styling Components.

courses.title: Python GUI Development with Tkinter
courses.synopsis: Put an end to writing command-line interfaces for your programs. Use Tkinter, the Python package for creating themed interface elements with the Tk GUI toolkit. Join Barron Stone in this course as he walks through the most popular Tk widgets and shows you how to customize their appearance and behavior to fit your application. Learn how to manage the placement of those widgets on the GUI and make them react to user behavior with event-driven code. The final chapter takes you through the entire start-to-finish process of building the user interface for an application, so you can see how all of these techniques work in a real-world development scenario.
objectives: Installing Python 3 and Tcl/Tk for Mac or Windows
Creating and configuring themed Tk widgets
Decorating the GUI with text labels and images
Capturing input from buttons, menus, and entry fields
Presenting choices with check boxes and radio buttons
Using geometry managers to lay out the GUI
Organizing widgets inside of frames and windows
Handling user actions with event-driven programming
Creating a simple drawing tool with the Canvas
Prompting users with pop-up dialog boxes
courses.comments:
This one took me probably about twice as long as it normally would have, because as I was going through it, I started working on my own Python GUI program, to somewhat replicate the contents of my Courses Jupyter Notebook, but with Menus and Treeviews, etc., using the Tkinter (pronounced "tee-kay-inter") module's widgets, along with pandas.
I'm about halfway done with what I want to do with that program, and will make it available, likely on GitHub or GitHub Gist, when completed.

courses.title: Learn Emotional Intelligence, the Key Determiner of Success
courses.instructor: Big Think - Daniel Goleman, Amy Cuddy, Susan David, Alan Alda, Angie McArthur
courses.synopsis: Explore the four domains of emotional intelligence—self-awareness, self-management, social awareness, and relationship management—as defined by psychologist and author Daniel Goleman. The domains build on one another, starting with a greater awareness of self and others, and ending with the management of relationships that are critical to your personal and professional life. Learn how to become more mindful of your strengths, limitations, and the values that define them; explore ways to create space between yourself, your thoughts, and your emotions; develop awareness of how people see the world differently based on individual preferences, as well as social and environmental factors; and use awareness of self and others to work toward collaboration, innovation, and mutually beneficial relationships. This course includes videos from: Daniel Goleman, psychologist, lecturer, and science journalist Amy Cuddy, social psychologist and associate professor at Harvard Business School Susan David, psychologist at Harvard Medical School and cofounder of the Institute of Coaching Alan Alda, Emmy-winning actor, writer, and director Angie McArthur, CEO of Professional Thinking Partners Note: This course was produced by Big Think. We are pleased to host this content in our library.

courses.title: WordPress 5 Essential Training: Site Administration
courses.synopsis: WordPress is an easy way to get a website up and running, but sometimes you want to take a WordPress site further. This course shows how to administer a self-hosted WordPress site. Learn how to work with the settings, including important privacy settings, and configure your site's style, menus, widgets, and theme with the Customizer. Find out how to extend WordPress with plugins, add and manage users, and manage comments and spam. Instructor Morten Rand-Hendriksen also provides tips for keeping your WordPress site secure and up to date—and troubleshoot it when something goes wrong.
objectives: Using the Customizer to adjust site identity and visuals
courses.comments:
This is a good companion course to this same instructor's WordPress 5 Essential Training course. Whereas that course covered content creation/management, this one went through every part/setting on a site's Admin page/Settings section.
We covered managing Users, their Privacy, and handling Spam, along with using Themes and other things. We ended with an excellent lesson on recovering from a site crash.
And I created a site template for myself, configuring the settings on it to his recommendations (or deciding from his explanations).

courses.title: WordPress 5 Essential Training
courses.synopsis: WordPress powers millions of blogs and websites. Available in 180 languages, WordPress can be hosted on any server, accessed in any browser, and built into almost anything you imagine: blog, portfolio, website, or online store. Learn how to create your own web experiences with this powerful and open-source publishing platform. Instructor Morten Rand-Hendriksen helps you get the most out of WordPress and create feature-rich blogs and websites. Morten explains how to create and publish posts and pages; create and edit blocks; and define reusable content blocks to take full advantage of the new block editor codenamed "Gutenberg."  Note: This course covers WordPress 5. The training will be updated as WordPress evolves.
courses.comments:
This is a good course, focusing on content management, using the powerful Gutenberg Block Editor.
I appreciated the Reusable Blocks feature, and the ability to use them to create templates, which I can envision being useful for creating Knowledge Base content.
Now on to the WordPress 5 Essential Training: Site Administration course...

courses.title: Installing and Running WordPress: Local by FlyWheel
courses.synopsis: Whether you’re just learning to use WordPress or busy developing new WordPress websites and themes, having a local version is essential. Installing WordPress on your computer gives you full control for experimentation, development, and testing. You see the changes you make immediately—no need to upload and download files. Local by FlyWheel is a free application that makes it easy to get a local WordPress environment up and running fast. In this course, instructor Morten Rand-Hendriksen helps you install and run WordPress locally on both Windows and Mac using Local. He then shows how to take advantage of all its benefits, including Live Link, local file access, cloning, and Blueprints, a special Local feature that makes launching your next WordPress site even easier.
objectives: Turning on and off local sites
Accessing and editing local files and databases
courses.comments:
Although I have experience managing Web sites on various platforms, I didn't have experience with WordPress. So I started taking the WordPress.com Essential Training course here. Then I realized that I should take the WordPress 5 Essential Training course, using the version from WordPress.org, which allows for more control, and which would likely be the platform in use at a place that I would work using/supporting it, instead. So I started taking that course, where the instructor recommended this course, to get a local installation of WordPress to work with.
Local by FlyWheel is pretty cool - you can creae WordPress sites that run in their own containers. And when creating the sites, you can choose between a couple of Web Servers, some PHP and some MySQL versions.
We learned how to turn on and off sites, clone and export them, and use a site as a Blueprint to create future sites from. We also learned about accessing the command line interface for WordPress.
Now back to the WordPress 5 Essential Training course...

courses.title: Serverless and Microservices for AWS
courses.synopsis: The benefit of serverless architectures are well-defined. Serverless helps developers focus on what they do best—building solutions—without the difficulty of managing and scaling infrastructure. However, when it comes to implementation, the instructions are much less clear. In this course, developer and AWS Community Hero Aileen Smith explores both the how and the why of serverless microservices architectures in AWS. Learn how to leverage Lambda functions and Elastic Container Service (ECS) components, choose the right integration technology, configure an API for access, and coordinate serverless workflows with Step Functions. Aileen also shows how to transition an existing application to serverless and solve common deployment and management challenges.
objectives: Transitioning an existing application to serverless

courses.title: Advanced Python
courses.synopsis: Develop your Python programming skills. Python is a great choice for building all kinds of applications, but to fully take advantage of its power and flexibility, you need to master all its advanced functionality. In this course, you can learn how to leverage next-level Python features such as object-oriented special class methods, use logging to track performance and user activity, see how to port code from Python 2 to 3, and make your code more efficient and easier to read and maintain. Instructor Joe Marini also shows how to manipulate data, build custom classes and functions, create lists, and write more elegant, optimized code.
objectives: Python comprehensions: list, dictionary, and set
courses.comments:
A very good course.
We learned about advanced collections, such as a namedtuple, Counters, and OrderedDict and Deque objects.
And we learned about adding object operations and comparisons to classes, and using the logging module.
We also learned about comprehensions - using a special syntax to derive a new list of values from an existing list of values. This syntax shortens the code (compared to using map), and can also be applied to dictionaries and sets.

courses.title: Learning React.js
courses.synopsis: React.js is designed to make the process of building modular, reusable user interface components simple and intuitive. In this course, Eve Porcello guides you through the foundations of React development, including the use of React hooks—a new feature starting in React 16.8 that allows developers to add functionality to components without writing classes. Eve shows how to create components, display dynamic data with properties, and render components using JSX syntax. Eve also manages the state of components with hooks; uses powerful React enhancements, such as the useEffect hook for loading remote data; and leverages cloud deployment options for apps created with create-react-app.  This course was created by Eve Porcello. We are pleased to offer this training in our library.
courses.comments:
This is a nice course on using React.js, an open-source JavaScript library used for building user interfaces.
And Create React App (create-react-app) is pretty cool, generating a React project structure. You can then modify the index.html, index.js and other files to create your app.
We learned about creating React Elements and React Components.
We finished up by generating a production build of our app, and putting it up on Netlify for hosting.
And now I have some React Native and GraphQL courses queued up...

courses.title: Introducing Entity Framework
courses.synopsis: Instructor Cam Soper introduces Entity Framework (EF) Core. EF Core is an object-relational mapper (ORM) that simplifies working with relational databases using strongly typed .NET objects. Cam shows you how to reverse engineer an existing database for use with EF Core. He explains that ASP.NET and EF Core are a perfect match to accelerate your web app development. He demonstrates how to use SQLite and Azure Cosmos database providers with EF Core. Cam concludes by exploring several ways you can optimize your EF Core code.  This course was created by Microsoft.NET. We are pleased to host this training in our library.
courses.comments:
In a prior course I took here, Building Web APIs with ASP.NET Web API 2.2, we used the Entity Framework (to work with/model databases). I wanted to learn more about it, and see why things were as they were in the Exercise Files we were provided with in that course.
Again, we used C#, this time for a Console app, and again using the Nuget Package Manager, this time to add the Entity Framework Core packages. Using that, we created a database and tables programmatically.
We learned how to use the Scaffold-DbContext NuGet Package Manager Console command to reverse-engineer an existing database, auto-creating classes for the tables, etc.
Then we used ASP.NET Core scaffolding with Entity Framework to auto-create Web pages to handle CRUD operations on the database.
We then covered other (than SQL Server) database providers - for SQLite and Azure Cosmos DB.
To get a SQLite database file of the SQL Server database we were using, I had to go find the SQL Server database files, attach them into my SQL Server instance, and find a converter that connected to that instance and converted the database to a SQLite .db file.
For the Azure Cosmos database Solution, I was barely able to see all of the connection properties (to his Azure DB) on screen, but did get it to connect and display our Create Product screen. But even after several attempts, I didn't get the Save to work, as he glossed over that, merely telling us that he already had the Models classes set up in his Solution.
We then learned some performance tips.

courses.title: SQL Code Challenges
courses.synopsis: Want to assess your SQL skills? These concise challenges let you stretch your brain and test your talents. Get hands-on practice querying and retrieving data, adding new tables to existing databases, updating data in multiple tables and multiple records, and presenting summary data. LinkedIn Learning staff instructor Scott Simpson structures each challenge in real-world scenarios: a restaurant website that takes reservations and online orders, and a library lending system. After each challenge, Scott shares his own solution. You can see how a professional programmer creates personalized, data-driven documents; handles sign-up data; deletes records; prepares reports; and more.
objectives: Composing SELECT statements to retrieve data
Adding data to more than one table
courses.comments:
I intentionally took a while to complete this course, working on a query or two here and there (while I was working on other courses) to stay sharp over time.
Even the most difficult challenges weren't too difficult, but I did learn about some of the differences in syntax between SQLite's SQL and other SQL flavors.
We used DB Browser for SQLite, and worked in databases for a restaurant and for a library. The challenge scenarios were interesting, as they would be typical for those entities.

courses.title: Building Web APIs with ASP.NET Web API 2.2
courses.synopsis: Learn how to connect web and mobile applications to back-end servers and databases in your applications using ASP.NET Web API 2.2, a popular framework for building web APIs on top of the .NET Framework. In this course, join Jonathan "J." Tower as he steps through how to use this framework to efficiently create RESTful services. Learn how routing works with Web API to ensure APIs work as planned and are easily consumed by remote applications. Discover how data is modeled in Web API, along with how to build business logic for your API. Plus, learn about handling errors, securing your services, and documenting and testing your APIs.
objectives: Binding your code to an HTTP request
Using exception filters and exception loggers
courses.comments:
This was a really good course.
We used C#, and covered different ways of routing requests, including using Data Transfer Objects (DTOs) to streamline requests/responses.
We covered error/exception handling, a couple of different ways to implement API documentation, and authorization and securing the API. I was glad to learn about securing all or part of an API, and do have some other courses queued up about this.
Postman, which I had used before, was the tool we used for testing the API, and we learned some tips and tricks for that tool, of which I hadn't been aware.
We used the NuGet Package Manager UI in Visual Studio to install packages for JSON Web Tokens (for Authorization) and Swashbuckle/Swagger for documentation. Earlier in the course, I became aware of/familiar with the Package Manager Console, when I had to do some things to take care of the differences between the current state of Visual Studio/.NET Framework, and things as they had been when this course was created.

I also had to troubleshoot a 
Could not find a part of the path '...\bin\roslyn\csc.exe'
error, and can pass on the simplest solution, if anyone is interested.

courses.title: Communication within Teams
courses.synopsis: Communication is an integral part of strong teamwork. In this course, Duke University professor Dr. Daisy Lovelace walks you through how to cultivate the communication practices of high-performing teams. She highlights the foundations of successful teams, and explains how to craft a team charter to establish norms for how you work together as a cohesive group. Dr. Lovelace also discusses essential elements of team communication—such as establishing trust and holding teammates accountable—and shows how to best communicate with your team in different settings.
objectives: Differentiate between the roles and responsibilities for team members.
Describe the purpose of a RACI matrix.
Identify the elements of a team charter.
Determine how best to manage conflict within teams.
Interpret which approaches should be used to manage virtual teams and cross-cultural team communications.
courses.comments: A good course on leading/participating in effective teams.

courses.title: Learning Java Applications
courses.synopsis: Get a practical introduction to Java programming, focused on developing Java applications for desktop, web, and mobile platforms. In this course, Todd Perkins provides a structured guide to Java application development. He reviews the basic building blocks of the Java language: variables, functions, arrays, conditional statements, classes, and more. In chapters 3 and 4, he shows how to build a user interface with Swing, the UI toolkit for Java, and connect Swing table components to different data sources. He also covers distribution and deployment of Java applications via JAR files, server-side programming with JavaServer Pages (JSP), and the Android development workflow. By the end of the course, you should know the basics of Java and be able to create simple desktop, web, and mobile apps of your own.
objectives: Storing data in tables and arrays
courses.comments:
I wanted to take this course because, while we created "console" applications in the other Java courses I have taken here, this course covered graphical applications, using Swing. And I have an old Java program that I created back after I first learned Java, that was graphical, which I used to place instruments in a space (stage, room, etc.) for MIDI files for my synthesizer, that I want to recreate. I can't find the source code for that. (It may be on a 3.5" floppy somewhere here). Back then we didn't have the nice Swing tools, and had to do everything from scratch in code.

We published runnable JAR files, including with resources, and installed Apache Tomcat and ran Java code from a .jsp page in our Web browser.
We ended up with installing Android Studio, based on IntelliJ IDEA, and created and ran a simple Android app. That was nice for me, since I'd only learned iOS development before.
In the bulk of the course, we used the Eclipse IDE and I found that its Code Completion is not as "smart" as other IDEs, such as IntelliJ IDEA, as it completes method calls, but not variables. It does, however, also alert you and make it easy to import libraries that you use in code.

courses.title: JSON Processing with Java EE
courses.synopsis: JSON is a ubiquitous and lightweight data transfer format used for the storage and interchange of information in an organized and human-readable manner. It is commonly used as the data format of choice in microservices, RESTful APIs, and NoSQL data stores. Knowing how to manipulate JSON is crucial knowledge for any developer.  In this course, discover how to use the Java Enterprise Edition (EE) JSON-Processing API. With its two programming models, JSON-Processing is one of the simplest ways to generate, query, and parse JSON data, and you'll find that implementing it in your projects is quick and easy. Join Alex Theedom as he covers an array of topics, including how to use both the object model and the streaming model, how to traverse a JSON structure, and how to parse JSON data using the extensive builder APIs. When you wrap up this course, you'll be ready to develop with this essential and powerful API.
objectives: The Java EE JSON object model
Creating a model from a JSON string
Outputting the JSON model to a data stream
courses.comments:
A good course on processing JSON with Java, using the JSON-Processing (JSON-P) API. It is similar to other languages' processing of JSON/XML.
And while probably not exactly "test-driven development," we did spend a lot of time writing tests to verify that our code worked (as opposed to just "printing" out the resultant JSON strings).
(We used the IntelliJ IDEA.)

courses.title: Introducing Jupyter
courses.synopsis: Present your projects like a pro with a new tool, Jupyter Notebook. Jupyter Notebook is an open-source web application that allows you to create and share documents that contain live code, charts and graphics, and descriptive text. It’s ideal for machine learning, statistical modeling, and other projects that require analysis and visualization. Join instructor Josh McQuiston as he shows how to run Jupyter notebooks, streamline workflows, and use common graphs to visualize your data in uncommon ways. The lessons are illustrated with examples based in real data, so you get an accurate picture of the real-world impact Jupyter can make on your development projects.
objectives: Presenting your notebooks with the slideshow feature
courses.comments:
I used Jupyter Notebooks in prior courses that I've taken here - pandas Essential Training and Docker for Data Scientists. During the pandas Essential Training course, I explored Jupyter Notebooks on my own, to see more of how they work, and what all was available. That led me to take this course, dedicated to this topic.
We covered all parts of the interface, the different modes, some good keyboard shortcuts, and Line/Cell Magic Commands, which among other things, allow for loading, running, and writing/saving external Python scripts in a Notebook.
As in the pandas Essential Training course, we covered plotting (graphs), sometimes more in-depth.
Finally, we exported our Notebook in different formats - HTML, PDF, and as an HTML Slideshow.

courses.title: pandas Essential Training
courses.synopsis: pandas is an open-source library that provides high-performance, easy-to-use data structures, and data analysis tools for Python. In this intermediate-level, hands-on course, learn how to use the pandas library and tools for data analysis and data structuring. Instructor Jonathan Fernandes dives into topics such as DataFrames, basic plotting, indexing, and groupby. To help you learn how to work with data more effectively, Jonathan takes you through a series of exercises that are based on the same large, public data set: the Olympic medal winners from 1896 to 2008.
courses.comments:
I'd used pandas in the last course I took here, Data Ingestion with Python - that was mainly in scripts, using, for example, Visual Studio Code.
In this course, our vehicle was a Jupyter Notebook. I'd used those before, in a Docker for Data Scientists course here, but that was mainly just setting up a Container to use as a dev environment.
In our Jupyter Notebook here, we used matplotlib for plotting our data (results), as well as Seaborn, a data visualization library based on matplotlib.
We used a nice dataset - the Olympic medal winners from all of the Olympics from 1896 - 2008 - their countries, events, etc., which allowed us to glean various insights.

courses.title: Data Ingestion with Python
courses.synopsis: A sizable portion of a data scientist's day is often spent fetching and cleaning the data they need to train their algorithms. In this course, learn how to use Python tools and techniques to get the relevant, high-quality data you need. Instructor Miki Tebeka covers reading files, including how to work with CSV, XML, and JSON files. He also discusses calling APIs, web scraping (and why it should be a last resort), and validating and cleaning data. Plus, discover how to establish and monitor key performance indicators (KPIs) that help you monitor your data pipeline.
objectives: Describe the characteristics of different data types and the work of data scientists.
Describe different data serialization formats and explain how to use them in Python.
Define APIs and explain how to use them with Python to make http calls, interpret JSON, and utilize message queues.
Explain what web scraping is and describe ways to do it.
Define what a schema is and describe characteristics of schemas and how they influence operations.
Describe the characteristics of different types of databases.
Categorize types of errors and explain how to correct them.
Explain design criteria for data systems and describe how to monitor performance using KPIs.
courses.comments:
I learned a lot from this course. Even though I hope to further understand what was behind all that we were doing, in the future, I did get more practice with pandas (a data analysis and manipulation library/tool for Python), as we used it throughout the course.
I also now have some nice Docker Containers - for Nats, a messaging system; a Redis key-value data store; a Neo4j Graph Database, for relationships; and one for an ElasticSearch document database.
I got some good experience working with CSV, JSON, and XML files, and APIs, as well as with various types of databases and a few Web scraping packages.

The instructor spent little if any time about getting some of the environments set up, so I struggled mightily with that - sometimes for every lesson. Along with the fact that some things in the accompanying files were wrong. Fortunately, in the Q&A area, other students helped with some of these problems, and I also used the Internet at large to resolve other issues. So, if any of you take this course and need help with such issues, please feel free to hit me up...

courses.title: Learning JDBC
courses.synopsis: Whether developers want to build mobile device apps for Android or web-based or desktop-based applications with the core Java SDK from Oracle, they must contend with the fact that many dynamic applications need to integrate data from a relational database. In this course, Frank Moley helps you get up to speed with the Java Database Connectivity (JDBC) API, showing how to use it to read and manage data from relational databases such as Postgres, Oracle Database, MySQL, and SQL Server in applications programmed with Java. Frank begins by going over key JDBC terminology, the basics of configuring a PostgreSQL database, and how to create the course project. He then provides detailed instructions on how to select and update data, work with transactions, handle exceptions, and more.
objectives: Creating, reading, updating, and deleting data
courses.comments:
When I first learned Java, JDBC didn't even exist yet, so I've been wanting to learn (about) it.
We connected to a PostgreSQL database in a Docker Container. I jumped ahead to the lesson in the PostgreSQL Essential Training course here that I have queued up about using a graphical interface, then installed pgAdmin 4 to connect to the database in the container, which made things easier than always using the Linux command line.
We coded the CRUD operations, implementing DAOs, including extracting/displaying data from a few table joins in a Master-Detail type of scenario.
We also used a stored procedure, covered transactions, and briefly covered exception handling, though not very much deeper than we used in our code.
The instructor briefly discussed the Java Persistence API (JPA), for which I already have a couple of courses queued up here, as well as Spring, so I guess I'll be going down more LinkedIn Learning rabbit holes...

courses.title: Cloud Native Development with Node.js, Docker, and Kubernetes
courses.synopsis: While the vast majority of Node.js apps are deployed and run in the cloud, few leverage all that modern cloud computing platforms have to offer. If you're looking to take the next step in your cloud computing journey, then this course is for you. Join Chris Bailey as he shows developers how to go from merely hosting apps in the cloud to building and deploying cloud native apps. Chris begins by providing an overview of what it means to be cloud native and create Node.js apps that exploit the cloud's features. He then steps through how to take an existing Node.js app and package it with Docker, deploy the app to Kubernetes, and enhance it with cloud native capabilities, including support for self-healing and metrics.
objectives: Deploying an app to Kubernetes using Helm
Adding support for metrics and request tracking
courses.comments:
I saw that a former coworker had taken this course, and I had taken Node.js and Docker courses here, and wanted to learn about Kubernetes. So this sounded like a good course for me...and it was.
We created Containers for a nodeserver - in dev and debug "flavors," as well as a "slim" production Container.
We used Kubernetes to deploy multiple instances of our app (a simple Web site/page, in this case) for load-balancing.
We set up a few endpoints so that Kubernetes could check the health of our deployments, to restart as necessary, as well as for metrics.
We deployed Prometheus to collect those metrics, and Grafana for a nice graphical dashboard.
Finally, we added Zipkin and Jaeger for OpenTracing.

As with other courses here, at times it was a bit of a struggle because of newer versions of things that are now available than were used in the course, as well as the pointed-to Web sites for acquiring the various things having changed.

courses.title: MySQL Essential Training
courses.synopsis: MySQL is one of the most popular database management systems for small- to medium-sized web projects. In this course, Bill Weinman provides clear, concise tutorials that guide you through creating and maintaining a MySQL database of your own. Bill explores the basic syntax, using SQL statements to insert, update, and delete data from your tables. He also covers creating a new database from scratch, as well as working with data types, operators, and string and mathematical functions. Plus, learn about the key differences between standard SQL and SQL as implemented by MySQL.
objectives: Creating and updating databases and tables
Working with string and mathematical functions
Differences between MySQL and standard SQL
courses.comments:
I wanted to learn how MySQL differs from Standard SQL and from the other SQL flavors that I've used, and to become more familiar with how MySQL Workbench operates.
Mission Accomplished.

courses.title: MySQL Installation and Configuration
courses.synopsis: Whether you're a developer, a database analyst, or just someone looking to manage data for their small business, having the ability to install and configure MySQL is a professional asset. In this course, join instructor Bill Weinman as he steps through how to install and configure MySQL on various platforms. Bill shows how to install MySQL on a Mac, as well as machines running Windows and Ubuntu Linux. He demonstrates how to create user accounts, assign database access privileges, and manage passwords. Plus, he goes over the different storage engine options in MySQL, including InnoDB.
objectives: Installing MySQL on macOS, Windows, and Linux
courses.comments:
I started taking this instructor's MySQL Essential Training course, and when we got to the part about importing the sample databases, he recommended this course, where he covers that process. (Another trip down a LinkedIn Learning rabbit hole...)
So I took a look, and since I had already done the installation in another course, I zipped through that chapter.
I imported the data, and also learned about user accounts, access privileges and roles, and password expiration, which I hadn't before. I created some other users, so I wouldn't be logging in as root, as I had been.
We also learned about the different database engines available in MySQL.
Now back to the MySQL Essential Training course...

courses.title: Learning Bash Scripting
courses.synopsis: Bash, or the Bourne Again Shell, is a widely popular command-line interpreter for administration and programming tasks. But Bash is different than most scripting languages. That's why Scott Simpson spends some time in this course running you through the syntax—introducing variables, numbers, and control structures—so you can start writing scripts right away. He shows you how to wrap up multiline operations in one file, implement flow control, and interact with users to get input. Plus, he offers challenges along the way that allow you to put what you've learned to the test.
objectives: Working with numbers, strings, and arrays
courses.comments:
Another refresher...
I was reminded of some things that I had forgotten - exact syntax, etc. - and got back up to speed.
Getting my development system set up, as laid out in this instructor's Learning Windows Subsystem for Linux course here, really helped. I was able to use VS Code on Windows, and execute on a WSL instance of Ubuntu 20.04. This allowed me to use one big script file for each chapter, remarking out each prior lesson's section as I went along. I included comments as to what we were doing and why. And once I completed the course, since I was using WSL, it was trivial to copy the directory there where I saved my scripts over to Windows, since I like saving all of the work I do in these courses here in a central location on my Windows machine.
And along the way, I created some command aliases that I wanted on WSL, and also looked up some common/recommended ones online, adding them to my .bashrc file.

courses.title: Learning Windows Subsystem for Linux
courses.synopsis: Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) is an optional feature of Windows 10 that provides a Linux environment for developers inside of Windows. Rather than managing your own virtual machine or relying on a remote Linux machine for development, WSL provides a Linux kernel and enables users to install various distros within their Windows environment. In this course, get up to speed with the basics of WSL and explore common tasks and procedures for developing with Linux. Instructor Scott Simpson steps through how to work in the Linux environment, explaining how to use the shell, manage services within WSL, and define automated tasks that run at predefined times. Scott also covers ways to integrate WSL into your workflow, including how to install the Remote-WSL extension to use Visual Studio Code in WSL.
courses.comments:
OMG, what a wonderful course!
I started taking this instructor's Learning Bash Scripting course as a refresher, and he mentioned this course. I took a look, and saw that it covered using Visual Studio Code on Windows, with files on a WSL distribution.
We installed Windows Terminal, which offers tabs into PowerShell, the normal Windows Command Line, and WSL distro shells. We configured it to open to a default profile/shell, in my case to a Ubuntu 20.04 WSL instance.
Even though I have WSL version 2 installed, my distros were running in WSL 1 mode - we learned how to change them to running in WSL 2 mode.
WSL provides seamless file access between Windows and Linux environments, i.e., you have access to the files on both systems at the same time. So, for example, you can run Linux utilities, like awk and grep, etc. against the Windows filesystem.
The instructor had us install the Remote-WSL extension in Visual Studio Code - this gave us the ability to have a remote shell into the Linux environment, and create/edit and run scripts there, right from VS Code in Windows.
Now back to the Learning Bash Scripting course!

courses.title: Blockchain Basics
courses.synopsis: We're on the precipice of a radical and disruptive new way of conducting all manner of transactions over the Internet. While still in its infancy, blockchain technology demands attention. In this introductory-level course, learn what blockchain is and what it might mean to you. Jonathan Reichental—named one of the world's top 100 CIOs in 2017—dives into blockchain technology from a conceptual perspective. The course is primarily non-technical by design, intended for those working in business leadership positions, data science, and IT management.  Jonathan begins by describing some of the current challenges with the Internet, including existing risks and security problems such as identity management. Next, he describes how traditional online databases function, so that you have a basis for how the blockchain redesigns this function. He then describes how the blockchain becomes a potential solution for many of the existing limitations of online databases. Since the blockchain has its genesis in Bitcoin—the digital currency—he provides some background on that too. He also discusses how blockchain technology actually offers new capabilities beyond simply solving old problems. To wrap up the course, Jonathan shares steps you can take in your organization to understand the implications of the blockchain.
objectives: List the core benefits of a traditional database.
Assess whether Bitcoin requires any intermediaries in a transaction or not.
Explain why blockchain technology is useful beyond cryptocurrency.
Identify some ways to reduce the risk of blockchain innovation.
courses.comments:
As with the IoT (Internet of Things), which I also took a course here about, I wanted to find out what THIS was all about. And this is a good introduction for that.
This course covers how (a) Blockchain works, its advantages and disadvantages, and presents the possibilities (far more than just cryptocurrency transactions), obstacles, and risks.
And as this course was from a few years ago, some of the things mentioned have already come to pass, e.g., the recent purchase of a(n) NFT for a piece of digital art.

courses.title: Designing RESTful APIs
courses.synopsis: Having a solid understanding of how to correctly build APIs is important for any developer planning on creating websites. In this course, learn how to plan and model your own APIs, and explore the six REST design constraints that help guide your architecture. Keith Casey starts with a simple overview, including advice on identifying the users or "participants" of your system, and the activities they might perform with it. He discusses how to validate your design before you build it, and explores the HTTP concepts and REST constraints needed to build your API. To wrap up, Keith goes over some of the most common API design patterns you may encounter.
objectives: Identifying activities and breaking them into steps
Mapping activities to verbs and actions
courses.comments:
A LOT of good information in this course.
While it (necessarily) presented information (HTTP Response Codes and the six constraints for REST APIs) also covered in the Learning REST APIs course here that I recently completed, this course went deeper.
We spent more time on Headers, and a lot of time on the processes of planning and designing. We also got into versioning and documentation.
I think that the key takeaway for me was the need for constant INPUT.
And I was reminded again, that the more I learn, the more I find that I didn't know, and the more I need to learn...

courses.title: Learning Node.js
courses.synopsis: Node.js is a platform built on the Chrome JavaScript runtime that can help you build fast, scalable network applications. Node.js uses an event-driven, non-blocking I/O model that makes it lightweight and efficient—perfect for data-intensive real-time applications that run across distributed devices. In this course, learn the basics of Node.js, and discover how to build a simple application. Alexander Zanfir goes into topics such as npm, reading and writing files, and Node.js frameworks. He covers Node.js features, such as async/await, and dives into popular web development concepts. Alexander also walks through how to build a demo chat app from start to finish.
objectives: Saving data to MongoDB with Mongoose
courses.comments:
A great course!
I'd used Node.js a little, taking the Polyglot Web Development course here. This got much deeper into things, also explaining npm (originally short for Node Package Manager) and package.json files.
As in the Polyglot... course, we used the Express Server. We also used Mongoose here, to connect to a MongoDB database.
The instructor had us create a free (Atlas) MongoDB Cloud account. That was cool, as I also put one of my local MongoDB databases up there, to use in the future for programming learning/experimenting.
We made API endpoints and used them to create a simple chat app, storing the messages in a MongoDB database (for persistence), and used Socket.IO for two-way communication, to "push" the messages back.
We then used Jasmine to create testing scripts to test our API, and and finished with an intro to test-first/test-driven development.

courses.title: Learning REST APIs
courses.synopsis: Learn the basics of REST APIs. In this course, discover what REST APIs are, why they matter, and how putting them to use can help you build faster, more efficient applications. Review how HTTP and REST APIs relate, explore the six constraints of REST, and learn about HTTP status messages. Learn how to get started with consuming REST APIs to incorporate them into data-driven applications.
objectives: Who or what interacts with REST APIs?
courses.comments: I've been using and writing Web APIs - this course gets into the nitty-gritty of what's going on with REST APIs, and how they work...

courses.title: Polyglot Web Development
courses.synopsis: Knowing multiple programming languages—and being able to pick up new ones quickly—makes you a more competitive and flexible web developer and freelancer. In this course, learn how to quickly pick up new web development languages and frameworks, including Node.js, Python, Perl, and Ruby. Discover the unique value each language brings, and how to build on what you already know. Plus, get hands-on practice with each language.
objectives: Exploring Node.js, Python, Perl, and Ruby code
Building on prior knowledge to learn new programming languages
Learning API read and write functionality in Node.js, Python, Perl, and Ruby
Implementing API functionality in Node.js, Python, Perl, and Ruby
courses.comments:
Excellent course, where we wrote Web APIs, pulling data from a MongoDB database, in Node.js, Python, Perl, and Ruby.
The instructor provided a Docker Container where everything was installed, and also provided direction to install the different platforms on our own OS.
So I did both - installed everything on Windows, and used the Container.
Wanting to have a consistent platform between the Container and my own installations, I decided to use the provided Dockerfile to build my own up-to-date Docker Image to create a Container from. Since things had changed from the time that the Dockerfile was created, I had a lot to figure out to make changes to build successfully.
The instructor also provided a Web page (HTML file) to have an interface which used the Web APIs to add, delete and update records from the MongoDB database. So I used this as a starting point, along with updating the Ruby code we ended up with, to modify that Web page to use with one of my own databases that I have in MongoDB.

courses.title: Python: XML, JSON, and the Web
courses.synopsis: Python is a powerful tool for working with data stored on web servers. In this course, Joe Marini demonstrates how to use Python to send, retrieve, and deliver web-based data to users. Learn how XML and JSON are used to store and exchange data, see how to use Python to retrieve XML and JSON data over the web, and find out how to parse that data using a range of different Python modules and features. Joe also shows how to fetch data from URLs and retrieve and send data via HTTP using the Python Requests library.
objectives: Retrieving and sending data over the internet
Using the Requests library to exchange data
courses.comments:
Good course on using Python to exchange data over the Internet, and in processing the XML or JSON data returned.
We connected to a Web site that had endpoints for using/testing GET, POST, etc., commands.
I appreciated that we were provided with a Docker command to run a Container of the site, so that the site could be used locally (i.e., disconnected from the Internet.) So I created Containers that used Port 80 and another port that didn't conflict with my IIS or Apache. And I added to the code in the Exercise Files here, so that I could switch between the live Web site and either of the two Containers.
We used Python's urllib module and also a third-party library, Requests.
We used the json module for working with JSON data, and the xml.sax API (Simple API for XML) for working with XML.
For XML DOM processing, we used xml.dom.minidom, and the ElementTree API (etree) in the lxml third-party library.
We used the pip tool (pip3) to install the Requests library and the lxml library (for its ElementTree API (etree)).
certs: CertificateOfCompletion_Python XML JSON and the Web_LI.pdf

courses.title: JavaScript and JSON: Integration Techniques
courses.synopsis: JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) has replaced XML as the core way of sharing data, especially when it comes to JavaScript, since it's so much faster, sleeker, and easier to parse. In this course, dive into working with JSON tools, designing JSON objects, and using different ways to handling JSON data. Author Ray Villalobos also shows how to use AJAX and jQuery to parse your data and feeds, and shows JavaScript and JSON in action in a real-world practical application.
objectives: Debugging JavaScript objects in the browser
courses.comments:
Another good course - a companion course to this instructor's JavaScript and AJAX: Integration Techniques course.
We covered using online JSON validation tools, and debugging JavaScript objects in the browser.
We also covered looping through JavaScript objects and accessing objects in arrays, for processing after bringing the JSON file in as a JavaScript object.
We learned a cool workaround for accessing (online) JSON files, where a file from another domain can cause problems due to cross-domain policy (JSONP).
Finally, we finished up with a project that used the Mustache.js logicless template library, in conjunction with the jQuery Cycle library, along with CSS styling to polish it up.

courses.title: JavaScript and AJAX: Integration Techniques
courses.synopsis: The ability to read data and communicate information asynchronously is fundamental to modern web applications. In this course, author Ray Villalobos takes a look at integrating AJAX (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML) with JavaScript and jQuery—a combination that makes it easy to work with dynamic data and reduces the number of requests to the server. The course first explains what AJAX is, and shows how to load and reload pages with pure JavaScript, update the DOM, and read and parse data in the XML and JSON formats. Next, learn how to read and write information between the server and the client with AJAX methods in jQuery, and build a dynamic search application that updates search results as you type.
courses.comments:
Excellent course about creating dynamic Web pages using AJAX.
We fed data from plain text, XML and (mostly) JSON files to Web pages.
And we worked with jQuery, making the calls simpler.
We created a page with a live search (with the search results from JSON data narrowing as the user typed into a search box), finishing up with a lot of CSS to style the page and its elements, including animations and transitions.

courses.title: Advanced PHP: Debugging Techniques
courses.synopsis: Debug your PHP code efficiently with a variety of client and server-side tools. In this concise course for experienced PHP developers, author Jon Peck demonstrates how to leverage PHP's built-in tools, as well as the Xdebug and Firebug extensions, and FirePHP libraries to improve the quality of your code and reduce troubleshooting overhead.  This course covers installation of Xdebug on Apache as well as working with the NetBeans IDE (integrated development environment). Jon then introduces native web browser developer tools for Firefox and Chrome, and demonstrates browser independent web debugging tools. Best practices for debugging and profiling web application failures and performance issues are also covered.
objectives: Understanding the principles of remote debugging
Extending your browser with Firebug, FirePHP, or ChromePHP
courses.comments:
This is a very informative and helpful course, but since it is dated (2012) parts of it took some work and digging to get through it (more on that in a bit...)
We configured PHP (in php.ini) to report errors, logged those errors to a file and sent in email, and learned how to gracefully handle them.
We installed and used Xdebug (in NetBeans) - displaying variables, used step-debugging, and set up profiling.
Xdebug was where some of my struggle occurred - the course was made with Xdebug 2, and Xdebug 3 is the current version, and what I used. Some of the functions used in the course were no longer available (not just deprecated, but non-existent). But I did eventually realize the version difference, and found this page: Upgrading from Xdebug 2 to 3.
That helped me with the functions, and when I struggled for quite a while getting the step-debugging connecting, I noticed the part about the port changing between versions. Well, THAT explained it! And I got it going...
We also covered browser extensions for PHP debugging, and I found the one for Chrome, ChromePHP, the most (currently) useful.
And, once again, I set up the Exercise Files on Apache and IIS Web Servers in Windows.

courses.title: Docker for Data Scientists
courses.synopsis: In a field where reproducible results are essential, Docker is rapidly emerging as one of the top tools for bringing efficiency to the work that data science teams—particularly those working in machine learning (ML)—are doing. Creating and developing ML models is often messy. Seasoned data scientists know that different versions of the same software can produce different results. With Docker, you can include the right versions of each needed dependency and library, so no one ever has to do any configuration. After the Dockerfile is built, you'll have exactly what you need. In this course, Jonathan Fernandes helps data scientists get up and running with Docker, demonstrating how to build a Dockerized ML application that can easily be shared. Along the way, he shares common use cases for the tool. Upon wrapping up this course, you'll be prepared to leverage the power of containers in your other ML projects.
courses.comments:
I did a mini-run on some more Docker, drilling in some more on Docker commands, Dockerfiles, etc.
We created a development environment Image with Python (Miniconda), pandas, seaborn, and Jupyter (along with data).
We then created Containers, exposing a port that could be connected through, and automatically running commands to open up a Jupyter notebook.

courses.title: Docker for .NET Developers with Visual Studio
courses.synopsis: Docker—a popular software containerization platform—can streamline the development process by speeding up the setup and configuration of environments. If you're a .NET developer who wants to employ containers in your application environment, this course can help by demonstrating how to leverage Docker in your workflow. Instructor Lee Brandt begins by discussing the role of Docker in the container world, and then goes over basic concepts, including how to run a container from a Docker image, and how to list and remove containers. Lee then walks through a sample project to lend a real-world context to essential Docker tasks, including how to add a Dockerfile to a Visual Studio project, and how to build a Docker image from a Dockerfile. He wraps up the course by discussing how to work with the Docker Compose file format.
objectives: How do containers compare to virtual machines?
Building an image from a Dockerfile
Running a container from a new image
Working with the Docker Compose file format
courses.comments: We created an Image and Container from a (provided) Web API Solution, creating a Dockerfile and a Docker Compose file, and pushed the Image to Docker Hub.
certs: CertificateOfCompletion_Docker for .NET Developers with Visual Studio_LI.pdf

courses.title: Learning PHP
courses.synopsis: PHP is still one most popular server-side languages used to build dynamic websites, powering everything from Facebook to Wikipedia. And although it is not especially difficult to use, nonprogrammers often find it intimidating. This introductory course was designed to change that by teaching you PHP through a series of clear, focused, and easy-to-follow lessons. After briefly explaining what PHP is, instructor Joe Casabona introduces the features of the language. He covers variables, control structures, calculations, loops, and functions, as well as includes and error handing, in a series of hands-on exercises. He then moves on to more advanced topics, including how to maintain state with sessions and cookies. Upon wrapping up this course, you'll have the skills you need to start developing and maintaining interactive websites using PHP.
courses.comments:
We covered the usual things for learning a language, such as variables, arrays, loops, functions, and objects, etc.
We also covered including external files and troubleshooting.
A LOT of time was spent on Forms - the form elements, validating for required fields, and validating and sanitizing the input.
We also sent email of the inputted data - Since I don't have an email server set up, I had to edit the php.ini file(s) for my Apache and IIS to use my Time Warner email account(s).
We finished up with reading and writing files, and using cookies and session variables.

courses.title: Advanced Java Programming
courses.synopsis: Want to get more out of the Java language and platform? In this platform- and framework-neutral course, instructor Bethan Palmer digs into some of the language’s more advanced features, helping you expand your programming skills as she equips you with techniques you can use when building applications anywhere Java is used: in web, mobile, and desktop applications. Bethan covers a variety of topics, including generics, working with the Collections Framework, and functional programming. Plus, learn about I/O in Java, working with files and directories, and structuring applications using the modular system available in Java.
objectives: Implementing a queue with a LinkedList
courses.comments:
In this course, we used the Apache NetBeans IDE. It's OK - the instructor didn't cover its workings/capabilities at all, so I can't really compare it to IntelliJ, beyond that it also works.
We covered Generics, and more on Collections, such as using a LinkedHashMap (similar to a Dictionary in other languages, but linked).
We also covered more on Functions, including method references, streams (as opposed to I/O streams, although we covered those as well) and parallel streams.
We covered modular structures and working with multiple modules, along with threading and multi-threading, and finished up with files and directories.

courses.title: C#: Interfaces and Generics
courses.synopsis: Take your C# coding skills to the next level by learning to use interfaces and generics in this course with programming expert Joe Marini. Interfaces provide a way of implementing common types of behaviors that can be reused across multiple classes. Interfaces keep your code nimble, compact, and efficient. Generics, on the other hand, help you work with strongly typed data collections, without having to commit to a data type ahead of time. Used in combination, these features make your C# projects easier to build and scale, with fewer bugs and performance issues along the way. Start watching to learn how to integrate interfaces and generics into your projects today.
objectives: Understanding how generics improve program reliability
courses.comments:
This course covered specifying and enforcing behavior(s) with Interfaces, both custom and the built-in .NET Interfaces.
It also covered Generics, as in this instructor's C#: Collections course. However, the programming challenge here was a bit more involved, as we used Delegates more so than in that course, and it involved using multiple Collection types in the same solution.

courses.title: C#: Delegates, Events and Lambdas
courses.synopsis: C# provides function types to fit a variety of scenarios, called delegates, events, and lambda functions. In this course, Joe Marini explores these key elements, starting with delegates, which allow developers to easily separate functional pieces of a program. Joe shows how to create both anonymous and composable delegates, using a shipping costs calculator as a practical example. Next, he covers using events to broadcast and listen to messages both inside and outside a program, switching functionality on and off on demand. Finally, the course explores lambda functions: concise ways to declare small and focused or one-off functions, which keep your program code tight and efficient.  Start watching to learn how to adapt this flexible set of programming tools to your own C# programming needs.
courses.comments:
In the C#: Collections course I took here by this same (excellent) instructor, which covered mostly Generic Collections, we used some Lambda expressions. I was unfamiliar with them, but in that context, it was straightforward enough for me to catch on.
He recommended his course, C#: Interfaces and Generics, so I started that one. Towards the beginning of that course, he mentioned that if we were unfamiliar with Delegates, which I was familiar with only in passing, to take this course.
Seeing that this course also covered Lambdas, I was able to get a better grasp of them, along with Delegates, which are quite versatile and powerful. We also covered (raising and) handling Events, as an offshoot of Delegates, in a context outside of handling UI Events such as mouse clicks, etc.
Now, back to the C#: Interfaces and Generics course...

courses.title: C#: Collections
courses.synopsis: Efficiently manage data with C# collection classes. In this course, join Joe Marini as he details how to maintain collections of data in C# and choose the right collection class to apply to a wide set of programming scenarios. Joe begins by covering basic concepts, including the difference between generic and non-generic collections and how to select a collection class to suit a specific programming problem. He then goes over basic collection classes, including how to use a LinkedList, and discusses specialized collections such as OrderDictionary and StringCollection.
objectives: Using the ListDictionary and HybridDictionary collections

courses.title: Leading without Formal Authority
courses.instructor: Lisa Earle McLeod and Elizabeth Lotardo
courses.synopsis: Leadership isn't just a skill for managers. Demonstrating leadership is important for employees at every level of an organization. There are opportunities to lead every day, whether you hold a formal leadership position or not. In this course, leadership and personal development experts Lisa Earle McLeod and Elizabeth Lotardo outline how individual contributors or SMEs can exhibit leadership by influencing, inspiring, mentoring, and motivating others. They also help you overcome unique challenges such as how to communicate when you think your boss or team is headed in the wrong direction.
objectives: Name three ways that you can add value to a meeting.
Recognize the benefits of including emotional impact in your stories.
Explain how developing a mindset can increase efficiency and productivity.
Identify an easy way to reinforce expectations.
Determine when it is necessary team to tell your boss about a mistake made by a peer.
Recall the most important benefit of punctuality.
courses.comments:
I had a role for many years where I had leadership responsibility, but without formal authority. So it was nice to see that there was actually a course about this.
I found that I had grown into doing some things right, had "grown" away from doing some other things right, and learned some new things from this course.

courses.title: Excel: Lookup Functions in Depth
courses.synopsis: Microsoft Excel offers a variety of powerful lookup functions that allow you to easily retrieve information across spreadsheets. In this course, Excel expert Dennis Taylor demystifies some of the most significant lookup functions. Tune in to learn how to use the new XLOOKUP function, which can handle all the capabilities of the widely used VLOOKUP and HLOOKUP functions, in addition to providing more power and flexibility. Explore uses of the MATCH function and the newer, more robust XMATCH function to match up data, and learn how to extract data using the INDEX function. Discover how to restructure the lists being searched to ensure that you're using each function efficiently, and learn about dynamic array lookup functions like UNIQUE, SORT, SORTBY, and FILTER. Along the way, Dennis shares practical examples that help you grasp how to implement these functions in your workflow.
courses.comments:
The last one, for now, on my roll of Excel courses here - a good refresher, along with some good new info.
I'd used VLOOKUP(), HLOOKUP(), and MATCH(), etc., before, but not XLOOKUP() and XMATCH(), new for 365.
I have Office 2019 Pro, so to get the X Functions, I had to download a beta version of the Add-in from GitHub.
The X Functions mostly worked using that Add-in, but since 2019 doesn't implement Dynamic Arrays, I had to find and use workarounds in some formulas.
And I was unable to follow along with the last chapter (except for the very last lesson), because the functions discussed were Dynamic Array functions, so were not available for me using 2019.
(But I did watch them all, anyway... ;^ ) )

courses.title: Excel: Power Pivot for Beginners
courses.synopsis: The Power Pivot feature in Microsoft Excel for Windows allows you to import, merge, and analyze data from many sources. Many people assume Power Pivot is a complex feature reserved for advanced users. Not so! In this short course, instructor Josh Rischin debunks myths around Power Pivot, explaining what it is and the best way to use it. Josh walks you through building a basic data model by identifying your data sources and creating data relationships. Then he shows how to analyze the data and present your results using PivotTables and PivotCharts.
courses.comments:
Learning more about PivotTables, etc., using the Power Pivot component, which I had to add to Excel as a COM Add-in.
Power Pivot allows one to add a Data Model, drawing from various sources, and easily set up Relationships between the sources. Calculations and Measures can also be added.
This course did cover PivotCharts, including using Filters and Slicers.

courses.title: Excel: PivotTables for Beginners
courses.synopsis: PivotTables don't have to be scary! This powerful Excel feature cuts the time you spend on formulas in half. In this concise course, Excel trainer Dave Ludwig demystifies PivotTables and shows you how to get started using them to analyze your data. Dave begins by explaining two PivotTable basic building blocks: value fields and row fields. Then he shows you how to adjust a PivotTable by adding fields, filters, and formatting. Finally, Dave shows you how to use special filter buttons which are known as slicers, and he also demonstrates how to use timelines. At the end, he goes over the basics of refreshing and updating a PivotTable.
objectives: Describe when you would use a PivotTable.
List the things you need to do prior to creating a PivotTable.
Explain the benefits of creating an Excel table before creating a PivotTable.
Describe a conceptual representation of the value field.
Cite the reason you should periodically refresh a PivotTable.
courses.comments:
I knew of PivotTables, and had a boss that lived in them, but hadn't used them myself. Turns out, they are a simple-to-use, powerful feature.
The interface for specifying the fields is like that used in Report Builder for SQL Server Reporting Services. In the course I took for that here, we didn't do much (if any) with Column Fields, so I was able to get a little experience with those here in this course. And it's nice to see the results immediately in Excel, without the need to run a report first, as in SSRS.
This course did not cover PivotCharts, but there are other courses here that do, and this course was a good, quick intoduction to PivotTables.
In any case, I'm now getting another tool in my toolbox...

courses.title: Implementing a Data Warehouse SQL Server 2019
courses.synopsis: Dimensional models like data warehouses can provide a more accessible and consistent form of data storage than relational databases. You can consolidate data from multiple sources into a single repository for business intelligence, analysis, and reporting. This course explains how to create a long-term data storage solution using local SQL Server instances and Azure SQL Data Warehouse. Instructor Adam Wilbert shows how to build a data warehouse from the ground up, starting with the tables and views; establish control flow; enforce data quality; and use your data in services such as SQL Server Reporting Services and Power BI. By the end of the course, you will be able to implement a robust, custom solution to serve all your organization’s business intelligence, reporting, and analysis needs.
objectives: Creating an Azure SQL Data Warehouse
Consuming data from the warehouse in BI services
courses.comments:
This is a great, info-filled course.
I was somewhat aware of data warehouses. Some coworkers had used "reporting" databases, but I don't know if those were built using a dimensional model, as we learned about here, or still in a (normalized) relational model.
Along with creating a data warehouse on a local instance of SQL Server, we also created a data warehouse on the Azure cloud, and moved the schema and data there.
We installed SQL Server Data Quality Services, and learned about cleansing data and creating a custom knowledge base for that. De-duping is also available with DQS.
We also installed and configured Master Data Services, which aims to keep data consistent throughout data sources for an organization.
We also used the MDS Client, and installed, configured, and used the MDS Excel add-in.
certs: CertificateOfCompletion_Implementing a Data Warehouse SQL Server 2019_LI.pdf

courses.title: IoT Foundations: Fundamentals
courses.synopsis: The Internet of Things (IoT) is more than just smart or connected devices. In this course, learn what IoT is, and how it works from a technical standpoint. Bruce Sinclair provides a broad overview of IoT, explaining each of its main components. He also goes into the software-defined product—the digital twin of the physical product—as well as the hardware-defined product, explaining how sensors and embedded systems help to gather data. Plus, he dives into the network fabric, and explains what external systems are and why it's important to consider them when designing an IoT product.
courses.comments:
With the IoT being a burgeoning area, I wanted to get an idea of what was going on.
And this is a good intro for that, mainly with realizing where the value comes in, as opposed to just smart or connected products.

courses.title: SQL Server: Reporting Services
courses.synopsis: Discover how to build, edit, and publish interactive reports using Reporting Services in SQL Server. In this course, author Adam Wilbert shows how to create, format, and share reports that leverage a variety of data sources. First, he takes you through the setup process, followed by the step-by-step process of building a report. He covers interactive elements, formatting, charts, sorting, filtering, web viewing, and mobile viewing. Adam also shares best practices, tips, and tricks that you can use to ensure your reports are dynamic.
objectives: What is SQL Server Reporting Services (SSRS)?
Viewing reports in the Power BI mobile app
courses.comments:
This was a very informative and even FUN course!
And what a great tool!
Years ago, when I worked at an R.O.P., I created the tables and charts used in the yearly financial presentation for the board. Then, I used Borland Quattro Pro for Windows (spreadsheet), and while it was powerful in its own right, it took a lot of manipulation to get things to look as I and my superiors were aiming for.
Oh, how I wish I had had a tool like this back then!
In this course, we installed and configured SSRS, used its Web Portal, and installed and used Report Builder and Mobile Report Publisher. Then, installing the Power BI app on my mobile devices, I was able to connect to the Report Server with them to view the Mobile Reports created.
I want to explore more with these Mobile Reports.
We also set up subscriptions to (non-mobile) reports.

courses.title: SQL Server Integration Services
courses.synopsis: SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS) is one of the core add-on components to SQL Server. With SSIS, professionals can create automated workflows that streamline the process of consolidating data from a wide variety of sources. Through a process called ETL—extract, transform, and load—you can ingest and move data between systems such as other databases, flat data files, and even online repositories. In this course, Adam Wilbert helps you get up and running with SSIS. Adam shows how to work with different control flow tasks, data sources, connections, and transformations. Plus, see how to add variables to control package execution, run packages with T-SQL, and more.
objectives: Managing and administering SQL with SSIS tasks
Making packages dynamic with variables and parameters
Scheduling packages with SQL Server Agent
courses.comments:
Wow, Microsoft has really done a great job here!
I had used the old DTS Packages feature/component to periodically populate a backup internal KB database, and to schedule (using SQL Server Agent) a Full-Text Index job to run nightly so that new KB Articles could be searched/returned.
But now, the packages are designed in Visual Studio and deployed from there into Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio. And the Visual Studio environment for this is wonderful! And powerful!

courses.title: Learning MongoDB
courses.synopsis: Excelling in an ever-changing software development world requires true "full stack" experience. Knowledge of nonrelational databases in particular adds exciting new capabilities and features that make everyday development easier, more streamlined, and vastly more scalable. This course provides an introduction to using MongoDB, one of the most popular nonrelational databases. Discover how to create documents to store data, organize documents in collections, and write queries to read, update, and delete documents. Instructor Justin Jenkins also shows how to properly index data to increase performance in MongoDB, and then shows how MongoDB can be integrated with applications written in Python, Node.js, and PHP. In the final chapter, he covers basic server administration, including replication, sharding, security, and backups. Make sure to practice your newfound MongoDB skills using the challenge and solution sets issued along the way.
objectives: Installing MongoDB on Windows and macOS
Writing queries to update and delete data
Coding with MongoDB and PHP, Node.js, and PHP
courses.comments:
I wanted to learn about a NoSQL database. MongoDB is a NoSQL database, and is a document database. (What is a Document Database?)
I got more experience composing and using JSON, as MongoDB stores its data as BSON (Binary JSON). (JSON and BSON)
Coding with MongoDB was one of the topic areas covered - in Python, Node.js, and PHP. To do this I had to install drivers for each of my installations of those, to connect them to MongoDB.
MongoDB seems very cool, I really enjoyed this course, and I want to delve more into it...

courses.title: SAP ERP Essential Training (2018)
courses.synopsis: The SAP ERP, or enterprise resource planning, platform helps large businesses streamline their processes and support each segment of their business, from sales to financial accounting. In this course, instructor Justin Valley helps you get started with SAP ERP, going over key concepts and tips that can help you use this enterprise software most effectively. Justin goes over the difference between technical modules and functional modules in SAP and explores key SAP modules, including SAP project systems (PS) and SAP human capital management (HCM). He also goes over how to navigate inside SAP as an end user, use various search methods to find data, run and export reports from SAP, and more.
objectives: Differentiate between master data and transactional data.
List different inventory modules in SAP.
Explain general menu navigation in SAP.
Describe basic report setup in SAP.
Determine basic report printing in SAP.
courses.comments: Learned a bit about an ERP system that I hadn't used...

courses.title: HTML5: Geolocation
courses.synopsis: This course shows how to add location tracking to a web application with a combination of JavaScript, CSS and HTML5. First, author and HTML5 expert Bill Weinman provides a thorough explanation of the geolocation API, including considerations every developer should take into account, such as data dependability, power usage, and privacy concerns. The course then covers how to detect support for geolocation, retrieve coordinates from a device (whether once or continuously), handle errors, and integrate the results with Google Maps to create a location-aware web application that will run on many mobile browsers.
courses.comments:
I had to (finally) add a self-signed certificate to my IIS to get SSL working, so that the browsers (especially on my other devices) would allow for using my location.
And I've started doing the same for Apache, which is a bit more of a chore...

courses.title: Python Essential Training
courses.synopsis: Due to its power and simplicity, Python has become the scripting language of choice for many large organizations, including Google, Yahoo, and IBM. A thorough understanding of Python 3, the latest version, will help you write more efficient and effective scripts. In this course, Bill Weinman demonstrates how to use Python 3 to create well-designed scripts and maintain existing projects. This course covers the basics of the language syntax and usage, as well as advanced features such as objects, generators, and exceptions. Learn how types and values are related to objects; how to use control statements, loops, and functions; and how to work with generators and decorators. Bill also introduces the Python module system and shows examples of Python scripting at work in a real-world application.
objectives: Python data structures: lists, tuples, sets, and more
Integrating a database with Python db-api
courses.comments: Drilling it in...

courses.title: Cloud Computing Careers and Certifications: First Steps
courses.synopsis: Do you want to start a career in cloud computing, but don't know where to begin?
